11001:
The vowels @deva[आ], @deva[ऐ], and @deva[औ] are called @deva[वृद्धि].

The sūtra has three words: @deva[वृद्धिः] (the term being defined), @deva[आत्] (the vowel @deva[आ]), and @deva[ऐच्] (the pratyāhāra covering @deva[ऐ] and @deva[औ]).

**The indicatory @deva[त्] in @deva[आत्]:**
- Shows that @deva[आ] has exactly two mātrās
- By @ref[1.1.70] (@deva[तपरस्तत्कालस्य]), it restricts the vowels to their standard length
- Even when @deva[आ] + @deva[आ] → @deva[आ] by sandhi, the result has two mātrās, not four

**Examples of vṛddhi substitution:**
- @deva[अङ्ग] → @deva[आङ्गः] "bodily"
- @deva[इच्छा] → @deva[ऐच्छिकः] "optional"
- @deva[उपगु] → @deva[औपगवः] "son of Upagu"

The term @deva[वृद्धि] appears in rules like @ref[7.2.1] @deva[सिचिवृद्धिपरस्मैपदेषु].
11002:
The vowels @deva[अ], @deva[ए], and @deva[ओ] are called @deva[गुण].

Whether original or derived, each of these vowels is a guṇa letter.

**Examples of guṇa substitution:**
- @deva[ऋ] → @deva[अर्] in @deva[अर्ति] "he goes"
- @deva[इ] → @deva[ए] in @deva[एति] "he comes"
- @deva[उ] → @deva[ओ] in @deva[ओखति] "he goes"

The term @deva[गुण] appears in rules like @ref[7.3.82] @deva[मिदेर्गुणः].
11003:
When @deva[गुण] or @deva[वृद्धि] is prescribed without specifying what it replaces, it substitutes for an @deva[इक्] vowel (@deva[इ], @deva[उ], @deva[ऋ], @deva[ऌ]).

This is a @deva[परिभाषा] (interpretive rule). Whenever a rule ordains guṇa or vṛddhi without naming the target, supply "@deva[इकः]" (of an ik vowel).

**Guṇa and vṛddhi correspondences:**
| Base | Guṇa | Vṛddhi |
|------|------|--------|
| @deva[इ/ई] | @deva[ए] | @deva[ऐ] |
| @deva[उ/ऊ] | @deva[ओ] | @deva[औ] |
| @deva[ऋ/ॠ] | @deva[अर्] | @deva[आर्] |
| @deva[ऌ] | @deva[अल्] | @deva[आल्] |

**Example:** @deva[नी] + @deva[अति] → @deva[ने] + @deva[अति] → @deva[नयति] "he leads"

**Why @deva[इक्] is specified:**
Long @deva[आ], diphthongs (@deva[एच्]), and consonants (@deva[हल्]) do not take guṇa/vṛddhi:
- @deva[या] + @deva[ल्युट्] = @deva[यानम्] (not *@deva[यनम्]) — @deva[आ] unchanged
- @deva[ग्लै] + @deva[शप्] + @deva[तिप्] = @deva[ग्लायति] (not *@deva[ग्लयति]) — @deva[ऐ] unchanged

**Why both terms are repeated:**
The repetition signals this rule applies only when guṇa/vṛddhi is explicitly ordained by name. When a vṛddhi letter appears without being called "vṛddhi," it may replace something other than @deva[इक्]:
- @deva[दिव्] + @deva[सु] → @deva[द्यौः] — @deva[औ] replaces @deva[व्], not @deva[इ] (@ref[7.1.84])
- @deva[पथिन्] + @deva[सु] → @deva[पन्थाः] — @deva[आ] replaces @deva[न्], not @deva[इ] (@ref[7.1.85])
11004:
Guṇa and vṛddhi do not occur when an @deva[आर्धधातुक] affix causes deletion of part of the root.

This excepts @ref[1.1.3]. Primary affixes are either @deva[सार्वधातुक] (marked with @deva[श्] or the @deva[तिङ्] endings) or @deva[आर्धधातुक] (all others).

**Normal case — guṇa applies:**
@deva[जि] + @deva[स्यामि] → @deva[जेष्यामि] "I will conquer"

**Exception — no guṇa when root-portion deleted:**
@deva[लोलूय] (intensive of @deva[लू]) + @deva[अच्] → @deva[लोलू] + @deva[अ] (य deleted by @ref[2.4.74]) → @deva[लोलुवः] "great cutter"

The @deva[ऊ] is not guṇated because the ārdhadhātuka affix @deva[अच्] caused deletion of @deva[य].

**Why @deva[धातु] is specified:**
Deletion of an anubandha or affix does not block guṇa:
- @deva[लूञ्] + @deva[इता] → @deva[लविता] — @deva[ञ्] (anubandha) deleted, guṇa still applies
- @deva[रिष्] + @deva[विच्] → @deva[रेड्] — @deva[व्] (affix) deleted, guṇa still applies

**Why @deva[आर्धधातुक] is specified:**
Sārvdhātuka affixes that delete root-portions do not block guṇa:
@deva[रोरूय] + @deva[तिप्] → @deva[रोरु] + @deva[ति] → @deva[रोरवीति] "he roars loudly" — guṇa applies despite य-deletion

**The @deva[इक्] restriction continues:**
Non-@deva[इक्] vowels can still undergo vṛddhi:
@deva[भञ्ज्] + @deva[चिण्] → @deva[अभाजि] — @deva[अ] → @deva[आ] despite ञ-deletion
11005:
Guṇa and vṛddhi do not occur when the affix has indicatory @deva[क्], @deva[ङ्], or @deva[ग्].

**@deva[कित्] affixes** (indicatory @deva[क्]):
- @deva[क्त], @deva[क्तवतु] — @deva[चि] + @deva[क्त] = @deva[चितः] "collected" (not *@deva[चेतः])
- @deva[क्त्वा], @deva[क्तिन्] — @deva[भृ] + @deva[क्त्वा] = @deva[भृत्वा] "having borne"

**@deva[ङित्] affixes** (indicatory @deva[ङ्]):
- @deva[अङ्] — @deva[विद्] + @deva[अङ्] = @deva[विदः] "knowing"
- By @ref[1.2.4], sārvdhātuka affixes without @deva[प्] are treated as @deva[ङित्]
- @deva[चि] + @deva[नु] + @deva[तः] = @deva[चिनुतः] "they two collect"

**@deva[गित्] affixes** (indicatory @deva[ग्]):
- @deva[ग्स्नु] — @deva[जि] + @deva[ग्स्नु] = @deva[जिष्णुः] "victorious" (not *@deva[जेष्णुः])

**The locative indicates occasion:**
The rule blocks guṇa/vṛddhi of both final and penultimate @deva[इक्]:
- @deva[भिद्] + @deva[क्त] = @deva[भिन्नः] "broken" — penultimate @deva[इ] unchanged

**@deva[इक्] restriction continues:**
Non-@deva[इक्] vowels can still take vṛddhi:
@deva[कम्] + @deva[णिङ्] = @deva[कामयते] "he desires" — @deva[अ] → @deva[आ] despite @deva[ङ्]

**Exception:** The @deva[ङ्] in tense markers (@deva[लङ्], @deva[लिङ्], @deva[लुङ्], @deva[लृङ्]) does not make them @deva[ङित्]. This is inferred from @ref[3.4.104].

@note[type=exception]{Optionally, @deva[मृज्] takes vṛddhi before kit/ṅit affixes beginning with a vowel: @deva[परिमृजन्ति] or @deva[परिमार्जन्ति].}
11007:
Consonants not separated by a vowel are called @deva[संयोग] (conjunct).

The term applies to the cluster as a whole, not to each consonant separately. The plural indicates two or more consonants may combine.

**Example:** @deva[क्क] in @deva[कुक्कुटः] "rooster"

**Why "consonants"?**
Two vowels together are not saṃyoga:
@deva[तितउच्छत्रम्] — the @deva[अ] and @deva[उ] are not saṃyoga, so @ref[8.2.23] (final deletion in saṃyoga-ending words) does not apply.

**Why "not separated by a vowel"?**
Consonants with a vowel between them are not saṃyoga:
In @deva[पचति पनसम्], the @deva[स] and @deva[म्] are not saṃyoga (they're separated by @deva[अ]), so @ref[8.2.29] does not delete @deva[स].
11008:
A sound pronounced through both the mouth and nose is called @deva[अनुनासिक] (nasal).

The sūtra has: @deva[मुख] "mouth," @deva[नासिका] "nose," @deva[वचन] "utterance," and @deva[अनुनासिकः] "nasal."

**Anunāsika vowels:**
Any vowel can be nasalized: @deva[अँ], @deva[आँ], etc.

Vedic example: @deva[अभ्र आँ अपः] (RV V.48.1)

**Anunāsika consonants:**
The five class-nasals are pronounced through both mouth and nose:
- @deva[ङ] — throat + nose
- @deva[ञ] — palate + nose
- @deva[ण] — roof + nose
- @deva[न] — teeth + nose
- @deva[म] — lips + nose

Semivowels @deva[य], @deva[व], @deva[ल] can also be nasalized.

**Why "mouth"?**
Excludes @deva[अनुस्वार], which is pronounced through the nose alone.

**Why "nose"?**
Excludes @deva[क], @deva[च], @deva[ट], @deva[त], @deva[प], etc., which are pronounced through the mouth alone.
11009:
Sounds with the same place of articulation (@deva[आस्य]) and the same articulatory effort (@deva[प्रयत्न]) are called @deva[सवर्ण] (homogeneous).

**Places of articulation (@deva[आस्य]):**
| Place | Sanskrit | Sounds |
|-------|----------|--------|
| Throat | @deva[कण्ठ] | @deva[क]-varga, @deva[अ], @deva[आ], @deva[ह], @deva[विसर्ग] |
| Palate | @deva[तालु] | @deva[च]-varga, @deva[इ], @deva[ई], @deva[य], @deva[श] |
| Roof | @deva[मूर्धा] | @deva[ट]-varga, @deva[ऋ], @deva[ॠ], @deva[र], @deva[ष] |
| Teeth | @deva[दन्त] | @deva[त]-varga, @deva[ऌ], @deva[ल], @deva[स] |
| Lips | @deva[ओष्ठ] | @deva[प]-varga, @deva[उ], @deva[ऊ] |
| Nose | @deva[नासिका] | @deva[ङ], @deva[ञ], @deva[ण], @deva[न], @deva[म], @deva[अनुस्वार] |

**Articulatory effort (@deva[प्रयत्न]):**

*Internal (@deva[आभ्यन्तर]) — at onset:*
- @deva[स्पृष्ट] (full contact) — stops @deva[क] to @deva[म]
- @deva[ईषत्स्पृष्ट] (slight contact) — semivowels @deva[य], @deva[र], @deva[ल], @deva[व]
- @deva[विवृत] (open) — vowels
- @deva[ईषद्विवृत] (slightly open) — @deva[श], @deva[ष], @deva[स], @deva[ह]
- @deva[संवृत] (closed) — short @deva[अ] in actual speech

*External (@deva[बाह्य]) — at release:*
- @deva[अघोष]/voiceless vs @deva[घोष]/voiced
- @deva[अल्पप्राण]/unaspirated vs @deva[महाप्राण]/aspirated

**Savarṇa groupings:**
- @deva[अ]/आ/अ३ are savarṇa (differ only in length, accent, nasality)
- Each vowel has 18 forms: 3 lengths × 3 accents × 2 (nasal/non-nasal)
- All consonants in a varga are savarṇa: @deva[क ख ग घ ङ]
- Semivowels have no savarṇas

**Both conditions required:**
- @deva[च] and @deva[श]: same place (palate), different effort — not savarṇa
- @deva[क] and @deva[च]: same effort (spṛṣṭa), different place — not savarṇa

@note[type=exception]{@deva[ऋ] and @deva[ऌ] are declared savarṇa by Vārttika despite different places. This allows: @deva[होतृ] + @deva[ऌकारः] → @deva[होतॄकारः].}

The term appears in @ref[6.1.101] @deva[अकः सवर्णे दीर्घः].
11010:
But @deva[अ] and @deva[आ] are always @deva[सवर्ण] with other vowels for purposes of @deva[प्रत्याहार] (abbreviatory notation).

The particle @deva[तु] ("but") indicates an exception to @ref[1.1.9].

In pratyāhāras like @deva[अच्] (all vowels) or @deva[अक्] (@deva[अ इ उ ऋ ऌ]), the initial @deva[अ] stands for all vowels of its class regardless of the strict savarṇa definition.

**Why needed:**
- By @ref[1.1.9], @deva[अ] (throat, open) and @deva[इ] (palate, open) differ in place — not savarṇa
- But the Śivasūtra @deva[अइउण्] must denote all simple vowels
- This rule makes @deva[अ/आ] "universal representatives" in pratyāhāras

**Result:**
When @deva[अ] appears in a pratyāhāra, it stands for:
- @deva[अ], @deva[आ] (its true savarṇas)
- @deva[इ], @deva[ई], @deva[उ], @deva[ऊ], @deva[ऋ], @deva[ॠ], @deva[ऌ], @deva[ॡ] (by this exception)

This is limited to pratyāhāras only, not to other grammatical operations.
11011:
A dual case-ending in @deva[ई], @deva[ऊ], or @deva[ए] is called @deva[प्रगृह्य] (exempt from sandhi).

Sanskrit normally does not allow hiatus — when one word ends in a vowel and the next begins with one, they coalesce by sandhi. But @deva[प्रगृह्य] vowels are exceptions (@ref[6.1.125]).

**Examples:**
- @deva[कवी इमौ] "these two poets" — not *@deva[कवीमौ]
- @deva[वायू इति] "two winds" — not *@deva[वायूति]
- @deva[माले इति] "these two garlands"
- @deva[पचेते इति] "they two cook"

**Why "dual"?**
Other numbers follow normal sandhi:
@deva[वृक्षौ] + @deva[अत्र] = @deva[वृक्षावत्र] (@ref[6.1.78])

**Why these vowels specifically?**
Duals ending in other vowels (like @deva[औ]) undergo sandhi normally.
11012:
The same vowels (@deva[ई], @deva[ऊ], @deva[ए]) after the @deva[म्] of the pronoun @deva[अदस्] are also @deva[प्रगृह्य].

This extends @ref[1.1.11] to forms of @deva[अदस्] "that" where @deva[ई/ऊ/ए] follows @deva[म्], regardless of number.

**Examples:**
- @deva[अमी अश्वाः] "those horses" (nom. pl. masc.) — not *@deva[अम्यश्वाः]
- @deva[अमू आसाते] "those two sit"

**Why "of @deva[अदस्]"?**
Other words with @deva[म्] + @deva[ई/ऊ/ए] follow normal sandhi:
@deva[शमी] + @deva[अत्र] = @deva[शम्यत्र]

**Why "after @deva[म्]"?**
@deva[अमुके] + @deva[अत्र] = @deva[अमुकेऽत्र] — the @deva[ए] follows @deva[क], not @deva[म्], so sandhi applies.
11013:
The Vedic affix @deva[शे] (@ref[7.1.39]) is @deva[प्रगृह्य].

In Vedic, the affix @deva[शे] sometimes replaces ordinary case endings. The @deva[श्] is indicatory; the actual affix is @deva[ए].

**Example:**
@deva[अस्मे इन्द्राबृहस्पती] — the @deva[ए] does not undergo sandhi.

In later imitation: @deva[त्वे इति], @deva[युष्मे इति], @deva[मे इति].
11014:
A particle (@ref[1.4.56]) consisting of a single vowel, except @deva[आङ्], is @deva[प्रगृह्य].

Single-vowel particles do not undergo sandhi.

**Examples:**
- @deva[इ इन्द्र] "O Indra" — not *@deva[ईन्द्र]
- @deva[उ उत्तिष्ठ] "O arise"

**Why "single vowel"?**
Particles with consonants follow normal sandhi:
@deva[प्र] + @deva[अग्नये] = @deva[प्राग्नये]

**Why except @deva[आङ्]?**
The particle @deva[आ] has four meanings where sandhi applies:
1. Diminutive: @deva[आ] + @deva[उष्णम्] = @deva[ओष्णम्] "lukewarm"
2. Reversive prefix: @deva[आ] + @deva[इहि] = @deva[एहि] "come"
3. "From/since": @deva[आजन्मनः] "since birth"
4. "Until": @deva[आ] + @deva[अध्ययनात्] = @deva[आध्ययनात्] "until study begins"

When @deva[आ] lacks these meanings, it may be pragrihya.
11016:
According to Śākalya, in non-Vedic literature, the final @deva[ओ] of a vocative singular before @deva[इति] is optionally @deva[प्रगृह्य].

The mention of Śākalya makes this rule optional.

**Both forms correct:**
- @deva[वायो इति] (pragrihya)
- @deva[वायविति] (with sandhi)

**In Vedic:** Sandhi is obligatory, not optional: @deva[एता गा ब्रह्मबन्धवित्यब्रवीत्].
11017:
According to Śākalya, the particle @deva[उञ्] before @deva[इति] is optionally @deva[प्रगृह्य].

**Both forms:**
- @deva[उ इति]
- @deva[विति]
11019:
In Vedic, final @deva[ई] and @deva[ऊ] expressing locative sense are @deva[प्रगृह्य].

By @ref[7.1.39], Vedic case-affixes are sometimes replaced by a vowel homogeneous with the preceding vowel.

**Examples:**
- @deva[तनू] + @deva[इ] (loc.) → @deva[तनू] "in the body": @deva[अध्यस्यां मामकीतनू]
- @deva[गौरी] + @deva[इ] (loc.) → @deva[गौरी] "on the Gaurī": @deva[सोमो गौरी अधिश्रितः] (RV IX.12.3)

**Why only @deva[ई/ऊ]?**
Other locative replacements (like @deva[आ]) undergo sandhi normally.
11020:
Words having the form @deva[दा] or @deva[धा] are called @deva[घु].

Six roots are @deva[घु]:
- @deva[डुदाञ्] "to give" — @deva[प्रणिददाति]
- @deva[दाण्] "to give" — @deva[प्रणिदाता]
- @deva[दो] "to cut" — @deva[प्रणिद्यति]
- @deva[देङ्] "to pity" — @deva[प्रणिदयते]
- @deva[डुधाञ्] "to place" — @deva[प्रणिदधाति]
- @deva[धेट्] "to feed" — @deva[प्रणिधयति]

**Effect:** In these examples, @deva[न] → @deva[ण] by @ref[8.4.17].

**Non-@deva[घु] roots:** @deva[दाप्] "to cut" and @deva[दैप्] "to clean" are not @deva[घु], so @ref[7.4.46-47] don't apply:
- @deva[दाप्] + @deva[क्त] = @deva[दातम्] "what is cut"
- But @deva[दा] (give) + @deva[क्त] = @deva[दत्तः] "given" (@ref[7.4.46])
11021:
An operation on a single letter applies to it as both initial and final.

When a word has only one letter, that letter is simultaneously its beginning and end.

**Example 1:** By @ref[3.1.3], an affix has udātta on its initial vowel. The affix @deva[अण्] (just @deva[अ]) is a single vowel — it receives the accent: @deva[औपगव॑म्].

**Example 2:** By @ref[7.3.102], final short @deva[अ] lengthens before consonant-initial case-affixes of @deva[यञ्] class. Even if the entire word is @deva[अ]: @deva[अ] + @deva[भ्याम्] = @deva[आभ्याम्] "by those two."

**Why "in one"?**
In words of multiple letters, initial ≠ final. This rule applies only to single-letter items.
11022:
The affixes @deva[तरप्] and @deva[तमप्] are called @deva[घ].

The actual affixes are @deva[तर] and @deva[तम] (the @deva[प्] is indicatory). These form comparative and superlative degrees.

**Example:**
@deva[कुमारी] + @deva[तर] = @deva[कुमारितरा] "more girlish" — long @deva[ई] shortens before @deva[घ] affixes (@ref[6.3.43]).
11023:
The words @deva[बहु] "many," @deva[गण] "group," and words ending in @deva[वतु] (@ref[5.2.39]) or @deva[डति] (@ref[5.2.41]) are called @deva[संख्या] (numerals).

The @deva[उ] and @deva[ड] are indicatory; the actual affixes are @deva[वत्] and @deva[अति].

**Words with @deva[वत्]:** @deva[तावत्] "so much," @deva[यावत्] "as much," @deva[एतावत्] "this much"

**Words with @deva[अति]:** @deva[कति] "how many," @deva[तति] "so many"

**Effect of being @deva[संख्या]:**
- @deva[बहु] + @deva[कृत्वसुच्] (@ref[5.4.17]) = @deva[बहुकृत्वः] "many times"
- @deva[बहु] + @deva[धा] (@ref[5.3.42]) = @deva[बहुधा] "in many ways"
11024:
Numerals (@deva[संख्या]) ending in @deva[ष्] or @deva[न्] are called @deva[षट्].

Six numerals: @deva[पञ्चन्] (5), @deva[षष्] (6), @deva[सप्तन्] (7), @deva[अष्टन्] (8), @deva[नवन्] (9), @deva[दशन्] (10).

**Effect:** By @ref[7.1.22], @deva[षट्] words lose nominative/accusative plural endings:
@deva[षट् तिष्ठन्ति] "six stand," @deva[पञ्च गच्छन्ति] "five go."

**Why "ending" (@deva[अन्त])?**
The @deva[ष्/न्] must be original, not added. So @deva[शतानि] "hundreds" and @deva[सहस्राणि] "thousands" (where @deva[न्] is an augment) are not @deva[षट्].
11025:
Words ending in the affix @deva[डति] are also called @deva[षट्].

By @ref[1.1.23], @deva[डति]-words are already @deva[संख्या]. This sūtra adds they're also @deva[षट्].

**Effect:** @deva[कति पठन्ति] "how many read" — @deva[कति] loses its plural ending by @ref[7.1.22].
11026:
The affixes @deva[क्त] and @deva[क्तवतु] are called @deva[निष्ठा] (past participle affixes).

The actual affixes are @deva[त] and @deva[तवत्] (the @deva[क] and @deva[उ] are indicatory).

Being @deva[कित्], they block guṇa (@ref[1.1.5]):
- @deva[कृ] + @deva[क्त] = @deva[कृतः] "done"
- @deva[भुज्] + @deva[क्त] = @deva[भुक्तः] "eaten"

The indicatory @deva[उ] in @deva[क्तवतु] triggers @deva[ङीप्] (@deva[ई]) for feminines (@ref[4.1.6]):
@deva[कृतवान्] (m.) → @deva[कृतवती] (f.)
11027:
The words @deva[सर्व] "all" and others listed in the Gaṇapāṭha are called @deva[सर्वनाम] (pronouns).

**The list includes:**
@deva[सर्व], @deva[विश्व], @deva[उभ], @deva[उभय], @deva[डतर]-words (@deva[कतर] "which of two"), @deva[डतम]-words (@deva[कतम] "which of many"), @deva[अन्य], @deva[अन्यतर], @deva[इतर], @deva[त्वत्], @deva[त्व], @deva[नेम], @deva[सम], @deva[सिम], @deva[त्यद्], @deva[तद्], @deva[यद्], @deva[एतद्], @deva[इदम्], @deva[अदस्], @deva[एक], @deva[द्वि], @deva[युष्मद्], @deva[अस्मद्], @deva[भवत्], @deva[किम्].

**Directional words** @deva[पूर्व], @deva[पर], @deva[अवर], @deva[दक्षिण], @deva[उत्तर], @deva[अपर], @deva[अधर] are @deva[सर्वनाम] only when indicating relative position, not as proper names.

**@deva[स्व]** is @deva[सर्वनाम] meaning "own," not "kinsman" or "wealth."

**@deva[अन्तर]** is @deva[सर्वनाम] meaning "outer" or "undergarment."
11028:
In a @deva[बहुव्रीहि] compound signifying direction (@ref[2.2.26]), these words are optionally @deva[सर्वनाम].

This is an exception to @ref[1.1.29] (which prohibits pronominal declension in bahuvrīhi).

**Example:** @deva[उत्तरपूर्वा] "north-east" (f.):
- Pronominal: @deva[उत्तरपूर्वस्यै] (dat.)
- Regular: @deva[उत्तरपूर्वायै]

**Why "direction"?**
To specify where option applies vs. where prohibition applies (in other bahuvrīhi types).
11029:
In @deva[बहुव्रीहि] compounds, @deva[सर्व]-words are not treated as @deva[सर्वनाम].

By @ref[1.1.72], rules applying to a word also apply to compounds ending in that word. This sūtra creates an exception.

**Example:** @deva[प्रियविश्व] "beloved of all" (bahuvrīhi):
- Dative: @deva[प्रियविश्वाय] (regular declension)
- Not: @deva[प्रियविश्वस्मै] (pronominal)

Similarly: @deva[प्रियोभयाय], @deva[द्व्यन्याय], @deva[त्र्यन्याय].
11030:
In @deva[तृतीया-तत्पुरुष] (instrumental determinative compounds), @deva[सर्व]-words are not @deva[सर्वनाम].

Another exception to pronominal declension.

**Example:** @deva[मासपूर्व] "prior by a month" (@deva[मासेन पूर्व]):
- Dative: @deva[मासपूर्वाय] (regular)
- Not: @deva[मासपूर्वस्मै] (pronominal)

This refers specifically to @ref[2.1.31] compounds, not general instrumental tatpuruṣa.
11031:
In @deva[द्वन्द्व] (collective) compounds, @deva[सर्व]-words are not @deva[सर्वनाम].

**Example:** @deva[वर्णाश्रमेतर] "castes, orders, and others":
- Genitive plural: @deva[वर्णाश्रमेतराणाम्] (regular)
- Not: @deva[वर्णाश्रमेतरेषाम्] (pronominal)

The word @deva[च] "and" signals the end of this exception series that began at @ref[1.1.29].
11032:
Before the nominative plural @deva[जस्], @deva[द्वन्द्व] compounds of @deva[सर्व]-words are optionally @deva[सर्वनाम].

This modifies @ref[1.1.31].

**Example:** @deva[वर्णाश्रमेतर] nom. pl.:
- @deva[वर्णाश्रमेतराः] (with @deva[जस्])
- @deva[वर्णाश्रमेतरे] (with pronominal @deva[शी])

This governs the next four sūtras. The option does not extend to @deva[अकच्]-words (@ref[5.3.71]): @deva[कतरकतमकाः] (pl.) — no option.
11034:
The words @deva[पूर्व], @deva[पर], @deva[अवर], @deva[दक्षिण], @deva[उत्तर], @deva[अपर], @deva[अधर], when indicating relative position (not as names), are optionally @deva[सर्वनाम] before @deva[जस्].

**Examples:**
- @deva[पूर्वे] or @deva[पूर्वाः] "the eastern ones"
- @deva[उत्तरे] or @deva[उत्तराः] "the northern ones"

**When names:** @deva[पूर्वाः] only — as in @deva[पूर्वं प्राप्नोति] "he reaches Pūrva."
11035:
The word @deva[स्व] "own," when not meaning "kinsman" or "property," is optionally @deva[सर्वनाम] before @deva[जस्].

**As pronoun ("own"):**
- @deva[स्वे पुत्राः] or @deva[स्वाः पुत्राः] "one's own sons"

**As noun ("kinsman/property"):**
- @deva[स्वाः] only: @deva[स्वा ज्ञातयः] "these kinsmen," @deva[प्रभूताः स्वाः] "much wealth"
11036:
The word @deva[अन्तर] meaning "outer" or "undergarment" is optionally @deva[सर्वनाम] before @deva[जस्].

**Examples:**
- @deva[अन्तरे गृहाः] or @deva[अन्तरा गृहाः] "outer houses"
- @deva[अन्तरे शाटकाः] or @deva[अन्तराः शाटकाः] "inner garments"

**Other meanings:** When @deva[अन्तर] means "between," it's not @deva[सर्वनाम]: @deva[ग्रामयोरन्तरे वसति] "he lives between the two villages."

Vt: When qualifying @deva[पुरि] "city," @deva[अन्तर] is not pronominal: @deva[अन्तरायां पुरि वसति] "he lives outside the city."

This sūtra ends the @deva[सर्वनाम] section that began at @ref[1.1.27].
11038:
Words formed by @deva[तद्धित] (secondary) affixes that do not take all case endings are also @deva[अव्यय].

@deva[तद्धित] affixes derive nouns from other nouns. When such derivatives take only certain cases (not all seven), they are indeclinable.

**Examples:**
- @deva[ततः] "thence" — ablative only (from @deva[तद्])
- @deva[तत्र] "there" — locative only
- @deva[यतः] "whence," @deva[यत्र] "where"
- @deva[तदा] "then," @deva[यदा] "when," @deva[सर्वदा] "always"
11039:
Words formed by @deva[कृत्] (primary) affixes ending in @deva[म्] or @deva[एच्] (@deva[ए], @deva[ओ], @deva[ऐ], @deva[औ]) are @deva[अव्यय].

@deva[कृत्] affixes derive nouns directly from roots.

**Affixes ending in @deva[म्]:**
- @deva[तुमुन्] → @deva[दातुम्] "to give"
- @deva[णमुल्] → @deva[स्मारम्] "remembering"

**Affixes ending in @deva[एच्]:**
- @deva[जीवसे] "to live"
- @deva[पिबध्यै] "to drink"
11040:
Words ending in @deva[क्त्वा], @deva[तोसुन्] (@ref[3.4.16]), and @deva[कसुन्] are @deva[अव्यय].

**Examples:**
- @deva[कृत्वा] "having done" (@deva[क्त्वा])
- @deva[उदेतोः] "having risen" (@deva[तोसुन्])
- @deva[विसृपः] "having spread" (@deva[कसुन्])

Vedic: @deva[पुरासूर्यस्योदेतो राधेयः], @deva[य ऋते चिदभिश्रिषः पुरा जत्रृभ्य आतृदः] (RV VIII.1.12)
11041:
The @deva[अव्ययीभाव] compound is also @deva[अव्यय].

@deva[अव्ययीभाव] compounds join an indeclinable with another word, typically ending in neuter singular/accusative.

**Examples:**
- @deva[अधिहरि] "upon Hari"
- @deva[अनुरूपम्] "accordingly"

**Effects of being @deva[अव्यय]:**
1. Case/feminine affixes are elided (@ref[2.4.82]): @deva[उपाग्नि प्रत्यग्नि शालाभाः पतन्ति]
2. The compound takes neuter gender (@ref[2.4.17])
3. Accent rules apply (@ref[2.4.18])

The @deva[च] "and" marks the end of the @deva[अव्यय] definition (sūtras @ref[1.1.37]-@ref[1.1.41]).
11042:
The affix @deva[शि] (@ref[7.1.20]) is called @deva[सर्वनामस्थान].

@deva[शि] is the nominative/accusative plural ending for neuters, replacing @deva[जस्]/शस्]. The @deva[श्] is indicatory; the actual affix is @deva[इ].

**Effects:**
- Lengthens penultimate vowel (@ref[6.4.8])
- Adds @deva[न्] (@ref[7.1.72])

**Example:** @deva[फल] → @deva[फलानि] "fruits"

Similarly: @deva[कुण्डानि], @deva[मधूनि], @deva[त्रपूणि]
11043:
The first five case-affixes (@deva[सुट्] pratyāhāra) — nominative singular/dual/plural and accusative singular/dual — are also @deva[सर्वनामस्थान], except in the neuter.

**The 21 case-endings:**
| Case | Singular | Dual | Plural |
|------|----------|------|--------|
| Nom. | @deva[सु] | @deva[औ] | @deva[जस्] |
| Acc. | @deva[अम्] | @deva[औट्] | @deva[शस्] |
| Inst. | @deva[टा] | @deva[भ्याम्] | @deva[भिस्] |
| Dat. | @deva[ङे] | @deva[भ्याम्] | @deva[भ्यस्] |
| Abl. | @deva[ङसि] | @deva[भ्याम्] | @deva[भ्यस्] |
| Gen. | @deva[ङस्] | @deva[ओस्] | @deva[आम्] |
| Loc. | @deva[ङि] | @deva[ओस्] | @deva[सुप्] |

The pratyāhāra @deva[सुट्] covers: @deva[सु], @deva[औ], @deva[जस्], @deva[अम्], @deva[औट्] (first five).

**Why "except neuter"?**
Neuter nom./acc. are handled by @ref[1.1.42] (@deva[शि]).
11044:
"May or may not" is called @deva[विभाषा] (option).

When both prohibition and permission exist, it's @deva[विभाषा].

**Three types:**
1. @deva[प्राप्त-विभाषा] — option after a general rule exists
2. @deva[अप्राप्त-विभाषा] — option without a prior general rule
3. @deva[प्राप्ताप्राप्त-विभाषा] — intermediate

**Example:** By @deva[विभाषा श्वे] (@ref[5.1.30]), @deva[श्वि] "to swell" forms perfect optionally:
- With samprasāraṇa: @deva[शुशाव]
- Without: @deva[शिश्वाय]
11045:
The @deva[इक्] vowels (@deva[इ], @deva[उ], @deva[ऋ], @deva[ऌ]) that replace @deva[यण्] semivowels (@deva[य्], @deva[व्], @deva[र्], @deva[ल्]) are called @deva[सम्प्रसारण].

**Correspondence:**
| Semivowel | Vowel |
|-----------|-------|
| @deva[य्] | @deva[इ] |
| @deva[व्] | @deva[उ] |
| @deva[र्] | @deva[ऋ] |
| @deva[ल्] | @deva[ऌ] |

**Examples:**
- @deva[स्वप्] + @deva[क्त] → @deva[सुप्तः] "slept" (@deva[व्] → @deva[उ] by @ref[6.1.15])
- @deva[वद्] → @deva[उदितः]
- @deva[यज्] → @deva[इष्टम्]
- @deva[ग्रह्] → @deva[गृहीतम्]
11046:
Augments with indicatory @deva[ट्] precede what they augment; those with indicatory @deva[क्] follow.

**@deva[टित्] augments (precede):**
By @ref[7.2.35], ārdhadhātuka affixes beginning with consonants (except @deva[य]) take @deva[इट्]:
@deva[भू] + @deva[इट्] + @deva[स्यति] = @deva[भविष्यति] "he will be"

**@deva[कित्] augments (follow):**
By @ref[7.3.40], Vedic @deva[तुक्] follows:
@deva[कुर्वतुक्कः] "the performer"
11047:
Augments with indicatory @deva[म्] (@deva[मित्]) come after the final vowel of the word.

**Example:** The augment @deva[नुम्] (actual augment: @deva[न्]).

@deva[पयस्] + @deva[नुम्] + @deva[इ] (@ref[7.1.72]) → @deva[पयान्सि]

The @deva[न्] inserts after the final vowel (@deva[अ] in @deva[पयस्]), not at the end of the word.

Similarly: @deva[मुच्] + @deva[शप्] + @deva[ति] → @deva[मुच्] + @deva[नुम्] + @deva[अ] + @deva[ति] (@ref[6.1.59]) = @deva[मुञ्चति]
11048:
When shortening is prescribed for @deva[एच्] vowels (@deva[ए], @deva[ऐ], @deva[ओ], @deva[औ]), the short substitutes are @deva[इक्] vowels.

**Correspondences:**
| @deva[एच्] | Short |
|------|-------|
| @deva[ए], @deva[ऐ] | @deva[इ] |
| @deva[ओ], @deva[औ] | @deva[उ] |

**Example:** By @ref[1.2.47], neuter stems ending in vowels shorten in compounds:
- @deva[अति] + @deva[रै] → @deva[अतिरि] "extravagant" (@deva[ऐ] → @deva[इ])
- @deva[नौ] → @deva[अतिनु] "disembarked"
- @deva[गो] → @deva[उपगु] "near a cow"

**Why "of @deva[एच्]"?**
Other vowels shorten normally: @deva[आ] → @deva[अ].
11049:
In a sūtra, the genitive case means "in place of" unless otherwise specified.

The genitive (@deva[षष्ठी]) can express many relations. This rule restricts its meaning in grammatical sūtras.

**Example:** In @ref[1.1.3] @deva[इको गुणवृद्धी], the genitive @deva[इकः] means "in place of @deva[इक्]" — guṇa/vṛddhi substitutes for @deva[इक्] vowels.

Similarly in @ref[1.1.48] @deva[एचोऽयवायावः], @deva[एचः] means "in place of @deva[एच्]."
11050:
When a class-term denotes the substitute, the member most similar to the original is the actual substitute.

**The problem:** @deva[गुण] includes @deva[अ], @deva[ए], @deva[ओ]. Which is the guṇa of @deva[इ]?

**Solution:** Choose by proximity. Both @deva[इ] and @deva[ए] are palatal — so @deva[ए] is the guṇa of @deva[इ]. Both @deva[उ] and @deva[ओ] are labial — so @deva[ओ] is the guṇa of @deva[उ].

**Four types of proximity:**
1. Place of articulation (@deva[स्थान])
2. Meaning
3. Notation (@deva[ग्रहण])
4. Quality (@deva[गुण])
11051:
When an @deva[अण्] vowel (@deva[अ], @deva[इ], @deva[उ]) substitutes for @deva[ऋ], it must be followed by @deva[र्].

By proximity, @deva[अ] is the guṇa of @deva[ऋ] (both are open vowels). But the actual substitute is @deva[अर्], not just @deva[अ].

**Examples:**
- @deva[कृ] + @deva[ता] = @deva[कर्ता] "doer"
- @deva[हृ] + @deva[ता] = @deva[हर्ता] "taker"

Similarly when @deva[ऋ] → @deva[इ] by @ref[7.1.100]: the substitute is @deva[इर्], not @deva[इ].
- @deva[पितृ] + @deva[भ्याम्] = @deva[पितृभ्याम्] → @deva[पितिर्भ्याम्] "by the two fathers"
11054:
A substitute prescribed for what follows replaces only the initial letter of that following element.

This excepts @ref[1.1.52] (which says substitutes replace the final).

**Example:** By @ref[6.3.97], @deva[ई] replaces @deva[अप्] after @deva[द्वि], @deva[अन्तर्], or upasargas.

The @deva[ई] replaces the initial @deva[अ] (not the whole word or its final):
@deva[द्वि] + @deva[अप्] = @deva[द्वीप्] → @deva[द्वीपम्] "island" (final @deva[अ] added by @ref[5.4.74])
11055:
A multi-letter substitute, or one with indicatory @deva[श्], replaces the entire original term.

This excepts @ref[1.1.52] (which says substitutes replace only the final letter).

**Multi-letter example:** @ref[2.4.53] @deva[ब्रुवो वचिः] — @deva[वच्] replaces @deva[ब्रू].
@deva[वच्] has 3 letters, so it replaces all of @deva[ब्रू]: future @deva[वक्ता] "he will speak."

**@deva[शित्] example:** @ref[5.3.3] says @deva[इश्] replaces @deva[इदम्].
Despite being one letter, @deva[इश्] is @deva[शित्], so it replaces the whole word:
@deva[इदम्] → @deva[इ] + @deva[तरम्] = @deva[इतरम्] "this one"
11056:
A substitute (@deva[आदेश]) is like the original (@deva[स्थानी]), except for rules based on the original's letters (@deva[अल्विधि]).

Operations applicable to or triggered by the original also apply to the substitute — but not for phonetic rules.

**@deva[स्थानी]** = what is replaced
**@deva[आदेश]** = what replaces it
**@deva[अल्विधि]** = rule conditioned on specific letters

**Example:** The gerund of @deva[ग्रह्] uses @deva[क्त्वा]. By @ref[7.2.35], @deva[इट्] is added before ārdhadhātuka affixes beginning with consonants (except @deva[य]). This is an @deva[अल्विधि] (conditioned on the initial consonant @deva[त्]).

If @deva[ग्रह्] → @deva[गृह्] by samprasāraṇa, the @deva[इट्] rule checks the substitute's letters — @deva[त्] is still initial, so @deva[इट्] applies: @deva[गृहीत्वा] "having seized."
11057:
A vowel-substitute caused by what follows is @deva[स्थानिवत्] for rules affecting what precedes.

When a vowel is replaced due to a following element, the substitute acts like the original for operations on preceding elements.

**Example:** Adding @deva[णिच्] (causative @deva[इ]) to @deva[पटु]:
- @deva[णिच्] causes vṛddhi of penultimate @deva[अ] (@ref[7.2.116])
- Before @deva[णिच्], @deva[उ] → @deva[अव्] by @ref[7.4.21]
- For vṛddhi, @deva[अव्] acts like @deva[उ] — so the @deva[अ] of @deva[पट्] gets vṛddhi
- Result: @deva[पाटवयति] "he sharpens"
11058:
A vowel-substitute is not @deva[स्थानिवत्] for these nine rule-types:

1. **@deva[पदान्तविधि]** — word-final rules
2. **@deva[द्वित्व]** — reduplication
3. **@deva[वरच्]** — the affix @deva[वरच्]
4. **@deva[य-लोप]** — deletion of @deva[य्]
5. **@deva[स्वर]** — accent rules
6. **@deva[सवर्ण]** — homogeneous letter rules
7. **@deva[अनुस्वार]** — anusvāra rules
8. **@deva[दीर्घ]** — vowel lengthening
9. **@deva[जश्-चर्]** — substitution of @deva[जश्]/चर्] consonants

**Example (पदान्तविधि):** @deva[अस्] loses @deva[अ] before dual/plural (@ref[6.4.111]): @deva[स्तः], @deva[सन्ति].
The @deva[लोप] substitute is technically present but invisible. For word-final rules (like @deva[औ] → @deva[आव्] before vowels), the @deva[लोप] is NOT @deva[स्थानिवत्]: @deva[कौ स्तः] "who two are" — no sandhi with the invisible @deva[अ].
11059:
Before a vowel-initial reduplicating affix, a vowel-substitute is @deva[स्थानिवत्] in form only during reduplication.

The substitute temporarily appears identical to the original for reduplication purposes, then reverts to its true form.

**Scope:** Rules involving:
- Long @deva[आ] deletion
- Penultimate deletion
- @deva[णिच्] deletion
- Semivowel substitution for vowels
- @deva[अय्/अव्/आय्/आव्] for @deva[ए/ओ/ऐ/औ]

**Example:** @deva[दा] "to give" + @deva[लिट्] (perfect):
- @deva[आ] is deleted before @deva[लिट्]
- But for reduplication, @deva[आ] "reappears"
- Reduplication: @deva[दा] → @deva[ददा]
- Then @deva[आ] deletes: @deva[ददौ] "he gave"
11061:
Affix-elision by @deva[लुक्], @deva[श्लु], or @deva[लुप्] is named after those terms.

When an affix disappears via these specific terms, the elision type is identified by that term.

**Examples:**
- @deva[अद्] + @deva[शप्] + @deva[ति] → @deva[अत्ति] "he eats" — @deva[शप्] is @deva[लुक्]-elided (@ref[2.4.72])
- @deva[जुहोति] "he invokes" — @deva[शप्] is @deva[श्लु]-elided (@ref[2.4.75])
- @deva[वरणाः] "city near varaṇa plants" — taddhita affix is @deva[लुप्]-elided (@ref[4.2.82])

**Why "of affix"?**
These terms only elide affixes, not bases. So @ref[2.4.70] elides affixes from @deva[अगस्त्य]/कौण्डिन्य], not the bases themselves.
11063:
When an affix is @deva[लुक्]/श्लु/लुप्]-elided, operations dependent on it do not affect the @deva[अङ्ग] (base).

Unlike @deva[लोप]-elision, @deva[लुक्/श्लु/लुप्]-elision causes the affix's "virtue" to vanish completely.

**@deva[अङ्ग]** = a base with respect to its following affix

**Example:** @deva[गार्ग्य] "descendant of Garga" is formed by @deva[गर्ग] + @deva[यञ्].
- @deva[ञ्] causes vṛddhi → @deva[गार्ग्य]
- In plural, @deva[यञ्] is @deva[लुक्]-elided (@ref[2.4.64])
- The vṛddhi effect vanishes: @deva[गर्गाः] (not *@deva[गार्गाः])

**Contrast with @deva[लोप]:** If it were @deva[लोप]-elision, vṛddhi would persist.
11064:
The portion from the last vowel to the end of a word is called @deva[टि].

**Examples:**
- @deva[अग्निचित्]: @deva[टि] = @deva[इत्]
- @deva[सामसुत्]: @deva[टि] = @deva[उत्]

The term appears in @ref[3.4.79].
11065:
The letter immediately before the final letter is called @deva[उपधा] (penultimate).

**Examples:**
| Root | @deva[उपधा] |
|------|------------|
| @deva[पच्] | @deva[अ] |
| @deva[भिद्] | @deva[इ] |
| @deva[बुध्] | @deva[उ] |
| @deva[वृत्] | @deva[ऋ] |

The term appears in @ref[7.2.116].
11066:
A term in the locative case indicates the operation affects what immediately precedes it.

**Example:** @ref[6.1.77] @deva[इको यणचि] — "@deva[यण्] replaces @deva[इक्] when a vowel (@deva[अच्]) follows."

The locative @deva[अचि] means the change happens to what precedes the vowel:
@deva[दधि] + @deva[उदकम्] → @deva[दध्युदकम्] (the @deva[इ] before the following @deva[उ] becomes @deva[य्])

**Why "exhibited" (@deva[निर्दिष्ट])?**
The preceding element must be immediately adjacent. In @deva[अग्निचित्], the @deva[इ] of @deva[अग्नि] is not directly followed by the @deva[इ] of @deva[चित्] (intervening @deva[च्]), so @ref[6.1.77] doesn't apply.
11067:
A term in the ablative case indicates the operation affects what immediately follows it.

As locative refers to preceding, ablative refers to succeeding.

**Example:** @ref[8.4.61] — "After @deva[उद्], @deva[स्थ/स्तम्भ्] assimilate."
@deva[उद्] + @deva[स्थानम्] → @deva[उत्थानम्] (the @deva[स्] following @deva[उद्] becomes @deva[थ्])

**Example:** @ref[8.2.18] @deva[तिङ् ङतिङः] — "A tiṅ-ending word after a non-tiṅ word becomes anudātta."
@deva[ओदनं पचति] — @deva[पचति] (following @deva[ओदनम्]) becomes anudātta.
But not @deva[पचत्योदनम्] — here @deva[ओदनम्] follows.
11068:
In this grammar, a word denotes both its form and meaning, except for definitions.

A rule about @deva[अग्नि] applies to the word-form @deva[अ-ग्-न्-इ], not to synonyms like @deva[पावकः] or @deva[ज्वलनः].

**Exception:** Definition terms denote what they define, not their own form. When @deva[वृद्धि] is used, it means the vowels @deva[आ/ऐ/औ], not the letters व्-ऋ-द्-ध्-इ.

**Why this rule?**
Unlike ordinary language (where "bring a cow" means the animal), grammar operates on word-forms. This prevents applying rules to all synonyms.
11070:
A letter with @deva[त्] before or after it refers only to homogeneous letters of the same prosodial length.

By @ref[1.1.69], @deva[अ] includes @deva[आ]. This rule restricts: @deva[अत्] means only short @deva[अ] (one mātrā), not long or protracted.

**Prosodial lengths:**
- Short: 1 mātrā
- Long: 2 mātrās
- Protracted: 3 mātrās

**Example:** @deva[आत्] in @ref[1.1.1] means specifically the two-mātrā @deva[आ], including its udātta/anudātta/svarita and nasal/non-nasal variants, but not short @deva[अ] or protracted @deva[आ३].
11071:
An initial letter with a final indicatory letter forms a @deva[प्रत्याहार] covering all intervening letters.

**Example:** @deva[अक्] = letters from @deva[अ] to the @deva[इत्] letter @deva[क्] = @deva[अ इ उ ऋ ऌ] (and their long forms).

**Why "final @deva[इत्]"?**
Resolves ambiguity. @deva[सुट्] could theoretically use the @deva[ट्] of @deva[औट्] (5 affixes) or the @deva[ट्] of @deva[टा] (7 affixes). Since pratyāhāras use final @deva[इत्] letters, @deva[सुट्] uses @deva[औट्]'s @deva[ट्] = first 5 case-affixes.
11072:
A rule about a particular item also applies to words ending in that item.

This is the @deva[तदन्त]-rule: rules about X apply to X-ending words too.

**Example:** @ref[3.1.97] says "@deva[यत्] comes after vowels." This means:
- After single vowels: @deva[इ] + @deva[यत्] = @deva[एयम्]
- After vowel-ending roots: @deva[चि] + @deva[यत्] = @deva[चेयम्]

**Example:** @ref[3.3.56] @deva[एरच्] — "@deva[अच्] comes after @deva[इ]."
- @deva[इ] + @deva[अच्] = @deva[अयः]
- @deva[चि] + @deva[अच्] = @deva[चयः]

Vt: This rule applies only to operations (@deva[विधि]), not to definitions or exceptions.
11073:
A word whose first vowel is @deva[वृद्धि] (@deva[आ/ऐ/औ]) is called @deva[वृद्ध].

**Examples:** @deva[माला], @deva[शाला] — first vowel is @deva[आ] (vṛddhi) → @deva[वृद्ध]

**Effect:** @deva[वृद्ध] words take special taddhita affixes like @deva[छ्] (@ref[4.2.114]):
@deva[माला] + @deva[छ्] = @deva[मालीयः]

**Why "first"?**
@deva[सभासंनयनः] has @deva[आ] but not first → not @deva[वृद्ध] → derivative: @deva[साभासंनयनः] (not *@deva[सभासंनयनीयः])

Vt: Proper nouns are optionally @deva[वृद्ध]: @deva[देवदत्त] + @deva[छ्] = @deva[देवदत्तीया] or @deva[दैवदत्ता].
12001:
Affixes after @deva[गाङ्] "to sing/recite" and the @deva[कुटादि] roots are treated as @deva[ङित्], except @deva[ञित्] and @deva[णित्] affixes.

This is an @deva[अतिदेश] (extension) rule. The root @deva[गाङ्] substitutes for @deva[इङ्] in certain tenses (@ref[2.4.49]). The @deva[कुटादि] class contains 40 roots from @deva[कुट्] "to be crooked" to @deva[कुङ्] "to groan."

**Effect — no guṇa:**
@deva[कुट्] + @deva[तृच्] → @deva[कुटिता] "one who acts crookedly" (not *@deva[कोटिता])

**Exception — @deva[ञित्/णित्] affixes cause guṇa:**
@deva[कुट्] + @deva[णिच्] → @deva[उत्कोटयति] "he makes crooked"

Vt: @deva[व्यच्] "to deceive" also follows this pattern, except before @deva[अस्]: @deva[विचिता], @deva[विचितुम्].
12004:
A @deva[सार्वधातुक] affix not marked with @deva[प्] is treated as @deva[ङित्].

@deva[सार्वधातुक] affixes are those marked with @deva[श्] or the @deva[तिङ्] endings (@ref[3.4.113]).

**The @deva[तिङ्] endings:**
| | Sg. | Du. | Pl. |
|---|-----|-----|-----|
| 3rd | @deva[तिप्/त] | @deva[तस्/आताम्] | @deva[झि/झ] |
| 2nd | @deva[सिप्/थास्] | @deva[थस्/आथाम्] | @deva[थ/ध्वम्] |
| 1st | @deva[मिप्/इट्] | @deva[वस्/वहि] | @deva[मस्/महिङ्] |

**@deva[पित्] endings (1st/2nd/3rd sg. para.) — guṇa applies:**
@deva[कृ] + @deva[उ] + @deva[तिप्] → @deva[करोति] "he does"

**@deva[अपित्] endings — no guṇa:**
@deva[कृ] + @deva[उ] + @deva[तस्] → @deva[कुरुतः] "they two do"

Here @deva[अ] → @deva[उ] by @ref[6.4.110] because @deva[तस्] is @deva[ङित्].
12007:
After @deva[मृड्], @deva[मृद्], @deva[गुध्], @deva[कुष्], @deva[क्लिश्], @deva[वद्], and @deva[वस्], the affix @deva[क्त्वा] is @deva[कित्].

These are @deva[सेट्] roots (take @deva[इट्]), so @deva[क्त्वा] would normally lose its @deva[कित्] nature by @ref[1.2.18]. This sūtra overrides that.

**Examples:**
- @deva[मृडित्वा] "having been gracious"
- @deva[गुधित्वा] "having wrapped"
- @deva[उदित्वा] "having spoken" (@deva[व्] → @deva[उ] by samprasāraṇa)
- @deva[उषित्वा] "having dwelt"
12008:
After @deva[रुद्], @deva[विद्], @deva[मुष्], @deva[ग्रह्], @deva[स्वप्], and @deva[प्रच्छ्], both @deva[क्त्वा] and @deva[सन्] are @deva[कित्].

**@deva[क्त्वा] examples:**
- @deva[रुदित्वा] "having wept"
- @deva[गृहीत्वा] "having seized" (samprasāraṇa)
- @deva[सुप्त्वा] "having slept"
- @deva[पृष्ट्वा] "having asked"

**@deva[सन्] (desiderative) examples:**
- @deva[रुरुदिषति] "he wishes to weep"
- @deva[जिघृक्षति] "he wishes to seize"
- @deva[सुषुप्सति] "he wishes to sleep"
- @deva[पिपृच्छिषति] "he wishes to ask"
12017:
After @deva[स्था] and @deva[घु] roots, @deva[सिच्] in ātmanepada is @deva[कित्], and @deva[आ] → @deva[इ].

The @deva[घु] roots are: @deva[दा], @deva[धा], @deva[दै], @deva[धे], @deva[दो] (@ref[1.1.20]).

**Examples:**
- @deva[उपास्थित] "he worshipped"
- @deva[अदित] "he gave"
- @deva[अधित] "he placed"

The @deva[आ] → @deva[इ] change is specific to these roots before āśīrliṅ and siñ.
12019:
After @deva[शीङ्], @deva[स्विद्], @deva[मिद्], @deva[क्ष्विद्], and @deva[धृष्], @deva[सेट्] @deva[निष्ठा] is not @deva[कित्].

**Guṇa applies:**
- @deva[शयितः], @deva[शयितवान्] "slept"
- @deva[प्रस्वेदितः] "sweated"
- @deva[प्रमेदितः] "become fat"
- @deva[प्रक्ष्वेदितः] "become moist"
- @deva[प्रधर्षितः] "violated"

@note[type=observation]{These roots (@deva[ञिष्विदा], @deva[ञिमिदा], etc.) are normally @deva[अनिट्]. They become @deva[सेट्] optionally when niṣṭhā expresses @deva[भाव] or "beginning of action" (@ref[7.2.17]).}
12029:
A vowel perceived with raised pitch is called @deva[उदात्त] (acute).

The @deva[उदात्त] accent is produced by raising the voice. In writing, it is unmarked (or marked with a vertical line above).

**Phonetics:** Pronounced from the higher portion of the place of articulation, with tension in the larynx.

**Example — @ref[3.1.3]:** "The first vowel of an affix has @deva[उदात्त]."
@deva[कृ] + @deva[तव्यम्] → @deva[कर्त॑व्यम्]
12030:
A vowel perceived with lowered pitch is called @deva[अनुदात्त] (grave).

The @deva[अनुदात्त] accent is produced by lowering the voice. In writing, it is marked with a horizontal line below.

**Phonetics:** Pronounced from the lower portion of the place of articulation, with relaxed larynx.

**Example — @ref[3.1.4]:** "@deva[सुप्] affixes and @deva[पित्] affixes are @deva[अनुदात्त]."
@deva[त्रयः], @deva[बोधयामि]
12031:
A vowel combining @deva[उदात्त] and @deva[अनुदात्त] is called @deva[स्वरित] (circumflex).

The @deva[स्वरित] is pronounced with combined rising and falling pitch. In writing, it is marked with a vertical line on top.

**Example — @ref[6.1.185]:** "Affixes with indicatory @deva[त्] have @deva[स्वरित]."
@deva[क॒न्या॑] (@deva[कन्] + @deva[यत्]), @deva[शि॒क्य॑म्], @deva[क्व॑]
12032:
The first half-@deva[मात्रा] of a @deva[स्वरित] vowel is @deva[उदात्त].

| Vowel length | @deva[उदात्त] portion | @deva[अनुदात्त] portion |
|--------------|---------------------|------------------------|
| Short (1) | ½ | ½ |
| Long (2) | ½ | 1½ |
| Pluta (3) | ½ | 2½ |

**Examples:**
@deva[शि॒क्य॑म्] — @deva[अ] is svarita: ½ udātta, ½ anudātta
@deva[क॒न्या॑] — long @deva[आ] is svarita: ½ udātta, 1½ anudātta
12034:
In sacrificial rites, @deva[एकश्रुति] applies except in @deva[जप], @deva[न्यूङ्ख], and @deva[साम].

During @deva[यज्ञ], mantras are recited in monotone. Exceptions:

**@deva[जप]** — whispered repetition; retains accents
**@deva[न्यूङ्ख]** — 16 types of @deva[ओम्]; retain specific accents
**@deva[साम]** — musical chanting; retains melodic accents

**In ordinary reading:** Mantras must have proper accents.
12035:
The word @deva[वषट्] may optionally be pronounced with raised accent or monotone.

Even in sacrificial rites where monotone applies, @deva[वौषट्] can optionally be accented.

**Both valid:**
@deva[सोमस्याग्ने वीही३ वौ॒३षट्] or @deva[वौ॑३षट्]
12036:
In Vedic recitation, @deva[एकश्रुति] is optional.

For ordinary recitation of Vedic texts, either accents or monotone may be used.

**Mantra portion:** Prefer accents
**Brāhmaṇa portion:** Some say monotone is obligatory

**Both valid:**
@deva[अ॒ग्निमी॑ले पु॒रोहि॑तम्] or @deva[अग्निमीले पुरोहितम्]
12038:
In @deva[सुब्रह्मण्य] hymns, @deva[देव] and @deva[ब्राह्मण] have @deva[अनुदात्त] accent.

This excepts @ref[1.2.37] for these specific words.

**Example:**
@deva[देवा॒ ब्राह्मा॒ण आग॒च्छत] "Come, O Devas and Brāhmaṇas"

The @deva[वा] of @deva[देवा] retains its original anudātta (does not become svarita → udātta).
12040:
An @deva[अनुदात्त] followed by @deva[उदात्त] or @deva[स्वरित] becomes @deva[सन्नतर] (extra-low).

@deva[सन्नतर] = lower than normal anudātta; occurs when:
1. Originally anudātta
2. Preceded by svarita
3. Followed by udātta or svarita

**Example:**
@deva[देवा मरुतः पृश्निमातरो॒पः]

In @deva[मातरोपः], the @deva[ओ] immediately before udātta @deva[पः] becomes sannatara.
12041:
An affix consisting of a single letter is called @deva[अपृक्त].

**Examples:**
- @deva[त्] in @deva[असेधीत्] (aorist)
- @deva[व्] from @deva[क्विन्] (@deva[क्], @deva[इ], @deva[न्] are @deva[इत्])

**Effect — @ref[6.1.67]:** @deva[अपृक्त] @deva[व्] is elided:
@deva[घृतस्पृश्] + @deva[क्विन्] → @deva[घृतस्पृक्]

**Multi-letter affixes are not @deva[अपृक्त]:**
@deva[दृ] + @deva[विन्] → @deva[दर्विः] "ladle"
12043:
In compound rules, a word exhibited in the nominative is called @deva[उपसर्जन] (subordinate).

In sūtras about @deva[समास], the word shown in first case (@deva[प्रथमा]) is the subordinate member.

**Example — @ref[2.1.24]:** @deva[द्वितीया श्रितातीत...]

Here @deva[द्वितीया] is in nominative — the accusative word is @deva[उपसर्जन].
@deva[कष्टम्] + @deva[श्रितः] → @deva[कष्टश्रितः]

**Rule — @ref[2.2.30]:** @deva[उपसर्जन] stands first in compound.

@deva[उपसर्जन] = that which loses independent character while determining the sense of the principal (@deva[प्रधान]).
12044:
A word fixed in one case while its companion varies is also @deva[उपसर्जन], but doesn't necessarily stand first.

When one member has fixed case-form regardless of the compound's case, it's @deva[उपसर्जन] for all purposes except placement.

**Example:**
@deva[निः] + @deva[कौशाम्बी] (always ablative sense):
- @deva[निष्कौशाम्बिः] (nom.) "having come from Kauśāmbī"
- @deva[निष्कौशाम्बिम्] (acc.)
- @deva[निष्कौशाम्बौ] (loc.)

The @deva[ई] shortens because @deva[कौशाम्बी] is @deva[उपसर्जन], but it doesn't stand first.

**Contrast — @deva[राजकुमारी]:** @deva[कुमारी] varies with case, so not @deva[उपसर्जन], @deva[ई] unchanged.
12054:
The @deva[लुप्]-elision rules need not be taught — the etymological meaning isn't current.

To derive @deva[वरणाः] (city name) from @deva[वरण] (trees) is unnecessarily complex. The city may have no such trees. Such words should simply be treated as proper nouns.

Rules @ref[4.2.69-70] (residence/vicinity) and @ref[4.2.81-82] (@deva[लुप्]-elision) become superfluous.
12055:
If etymological meaning were authoritative, words should vanish when that meaning is absent.

If @deva[पञ्चालाः] meant "land where Pañcālas live," it should cease when they no longer live there. But these words persist — proving they're conventional names, not etymological derivatives.

Such words are @deva[रूढि] — their meaning is fixed by usage, not derivation.
12056:
The rule that meaning depends on the principal word or affix need not be taught — meaning is established otherwise.

Some grammarians held that:
- Compound meaning = principal member's meaning
- Derivative meaning = affix's meaning

Pāṇini refutes this: meaning is fixed by usage. A person knowing no grammar understands @deva[राजपुरुष] means "king's man," not "king" or "any man."

The proof of meaning lies in convention, not grammatical analysis.
12057:
Rules defining tense and @deva[उपसर्जन] are equally unnecessary.

Some defined @deva[अद्यतन] ("today") as "from rising to sleeping" or "midnight to midnight." Such definitions are redundant — common people use tenses correctly without grammar.

Similarly, @deva[उपसर्जन] ("subordinate") need not be defined — people naturally say @deva[उपसर्जनम्] for "being secondary."

Other unspoken rules (like "bahuvrīhi denotes possession") are understood by convention.
12060:
The dual of @deva[फाल्गुनी] and @deva[प्रोष्ठपदा] (asterisms) may optionally be plural.

**Both valid:**
@deva[उदिते पूर्वे फल्गुन्यौ] (dual) or @deva[उदिताः पूर्वाः फल्गुन्यः] (plural)

**As asterism names only:**
When not naming stars: @deva[फल्गुन्यौ माणविके] "two girls named Phalgunī" — only dual.
12069:
A neuter word may optionally be retained over masculine/feminine, and the result is singular-like.

When neuter is one of the words:
- Neuter prevails over masc./fem.
- Result acts like singular

**Example:**
@deva[आलस्यः] (m.) + @deva[मैथुनम्] (n.) + @deva[निद्रा] (f.) → @deva[सेव्यमानम्] "when indulged"

The adjective is neuter singular.

**Neuter + neuter — normal plural:**
@deva[शुक्लम्] × 3 → @deva[शुक्लानि]
12070:
When @deva[पितृ] and @deva[मातृ] stand together, @deva[पितृ] is optionally retained.

**Both valid:**
@deva[पिता] + @deva[माता] → @deva[पितरौ] or @deva[मातापितरौ] "parents"

Yājñavalkya Smṛti uses @deva[पितरौ] for "father and mother."
13001:
Words beginning with @deva[भू] "to become" that denote action are called @deva[धातु] (verbal root).

Sanskrit grammarians list ~2000 roots divided into 10 classes based on modifications before certain affixes:

| Class | Name | Example |
|-------|------|--------|
| 1 | @deva[भ्वादि] | @deva[भू] |
| 2 | @deva[अदादि] | @deva[अद्] |
| 3 | @deva[जुहोत्यादि] | @deva[हु] |
| 4 | @deva[दिवादि] | @deva[दिव्] |
| 5 | @deva[स्वादि] | @deva[सु] |
| 6 | @deva[तुदादि] | @deva[तुद्] |
| 7 | @deva[रुधादि] | @deva[रुध्] |
| 8 | @deva[तनादि] | @deva[तन्] |
| 9 | @deva[क्र्यादि] | @deva[क्री] |
| 10 | @deva[चुरादि] | @deva[चुर्] |

Roots take either @deva[परस्मैपद] or @deva[आत्मनेपद] endings (or both). This chapter primarily determines which @deva[पद] a root takes.

The @deva[वा] in @deva[भूवादि] is for auspiciousness — the regular sandhi would be @deva[भ्वादि].
13002:
Nasalized vowels in @deva[उपदेश] (technical enunciation) are @deva[इत्] (indicatory).

@deva[उपदेश] = first mention of a form in sūtrapāṭha, gaṇapāṭha, or dhātupāṭha.

**Examples:**
- @deva[क्विँन्] — the nasalized @deva[इ] is @deva[इत्]
- @deva[ञिमिदा] — the nasalized portion marks the root as taking @deva[क्त] in present sense (@ref[3.2.187])

**Not @deva[उपदेश] — not @deva[इत्]:**
In Vedic @deva[अभ्र आँ अपः], the nasalized @deva[आ] is a real particle, not indicatory.

**Vowels only:**
In affix @deva[मनिँन्] (@ref[3.2.74]), the nasality is on @deva[इ], not @deva[न्], so only @deva[इ] is @deva[इत्].
13003:
The final consonant of a root, affix, etc. in @deva[उपदेश] is @deva[इत्].

**In pratyāhāra sūtras:**
- @deva[अइउण्] — @deva[ण्] is @deva[इत्]
- @deva[ऋऌक्] — @deva[क्] is @deva[इत्]
- @deva[एओङ्] — @deva[ङ्] is @deva[इत्]
- @deva[ऐऔच्] — @deva[च्] is @deva[इत्]

**Only in @deva[उपदेश]:**
In complete words like @deva[अग्निचित्] "fire-piler" or @deva[सोमसुत्] "soma-presser," the final consonants are not @deva[इत्].
13005:
Initial @deva[ञि], @deva[टु], and @deva[डु] are @deva[इत्].

**@deva[ञि] — indicates @deva[क्त] has present sense (@ref[3.2.187]):**
- @deva[ञिमिदा] → real root @deva[मिद्] → @deva[मिन्नः] "fat"
- @deva[ञिफला] → @deva[फुल्लः] "blossomed"
- @deva[ञिइन्धी] → @deva[इद्धः] "kindled"

**@deva[टु] — takes affix @deva[अथु] (@ref[3.3.89]):**
- @deva[टुवेपृ] → @deva[वेपथुः] "trembling"
- @deva[टुओश्वि] → @deva[श्वयथुः] "swelling"

**@deva[डु] — takes affix @deva[त्रिम] (@ref[3.3.88]):**
- @deva[डुकृञ्] → @deva[कृत्रिमम्] "artificial"
- @deva[डुपचष्] → @deva[पक्त्रिमम्] "cooked"

**Not initial — not @deva[इत्]:**
@deva[पटूयति], @deva[कण्डूयति] — the @deva[टु/डु] is not initial.
13006:
Initial @deva[ष्] of an affix is @deva[इत्].

**Example — @ref[3.1.145]:**
@deva[नृत्] + @deva[ष्वुन्] → @deva[नर्त्] + @deva[अक] (@ref[7.1.1]) → @deva[नर्तकः] "dancer"

**Effect of @deva[षित्]:**
Feminine takes @deva[ङीष्] (@ref[4.1.41]): @deva[नर्तकी]

**Only affixes:**
In words like @deva[षोड] "six" or @deva[षडिक], the @deva[ष्] is not @deva[इत्].

**Must be initial:**
In @deva[टिषच्] (@deva[अविमह्योष्टिषच्], Uṇ. I.45), the @deva[ष्] is not initial: @deva[अविषः] "ocean," @deva[महिषः] "buffalo."
13007:
Initial palatals and linguals of an affix are @deva[इत्].

The consonants @deva[च् छ् ज् झ् ञ् ट् ठ् ड् ढ् ण्] are @deva[इत्] when initial in affixes.

| Letter | Example | Result |
|--------|---------|--------|
| @deva[च्] | @deva[च्फञ्] (@ref[4.1.98]) | @deva[कौञ्चायन्यः] |
| @deva[छ्] | replaced by @deva[ईय] (@ref[7.1.2]) | |
| @deva[ज्] | @deva[जस्] (nom. pl.) | @deva[ब्राह्मणाः] |
| @deva[झ्] | replaced by @deva[अन्त] (@ref[7.1.3]) | @deva[भवन्ति] |
| @deva[ञ्] | @deva[ञ्य] (@ref[4.3.92]) | @deva[शाण्डिक्यः] |
| @deva[ट्] | @deva[ट] (@ref[3.2.16]) | @deva[कुरुचरः] |
| @deva[ठ्] | replaced by @deva[इक] (@ref[7.3.50]) | |
| @deva[ड्] | @deva[ड] (@ref[3.2.97]) | @deva[उपसरजः] |
| @deva[ढ्] | replaced by @deva[एय] (@ref[7.1.2]) | |
| @deva[ण्] | @deva[ण] (@ref[4.4.85]) | @deva[आन्नः] |

@note[type=exception]{This rule is @deva[अनित्य]. In @deva[चुञ्चुप्], @deva[चणप्] (@ref[5.2.26]), the @deva[च्] is not @deva[इत्]: @deva[विद्याचुंचुः]. In @deva[टीटच्] (@ref[5.2.31]), the @deva[ट्] is not @deva[इत्]: @deva[अवटीटम्] "flat-nosed."}
13008:
Initial @deva[ल्], @deva[श्], and gutturals of non-@deva[तद्धित] affixes are @deva[इत्].

| Letter | Example | Result |
|--------|---------|--------|
| @deva[ल्] | @deva[ल्युट्] (@ref[3.3.115]) | @deva[चयनम्] "collecting" |
| @deva[श्] | @deva[शप्] (@ref[3.1.68]) | @deva[भवति] |
| @deva[क्] | @deva[क्त], @deva[क्तवतु] | @deva[भुक्तः] |
| @deva[ख्] | @deva[खच्] (@ref[3.2.38]) | @deva[प्रियंवदः] |
| @deva[ग्] | @deva[ग्स्नु] (@ref[3.2.139]) | @deva[जिष्णुः] |
| @deva[घ्] | @deva[घुरच्] (@ref[3.2.161]) | @deva[भङ्गुरम्] |
| @deva[ङ्] | @deva[ङसि], @deva[ङस्] | @deva[सुमनसः] |

**In @deva[तद्धित] — not @deva[इत्]:**
- @deva[चूडा] + @deva[लच्] → @deva[चूडालः] "crested" (@ref[5.2.96])
- @deva[लोम] + @deva[श] → @deva[लोमशः] "hairy" (@ref[5.2.100])
- @deva[वृक्ष] + @deva[कन्] → @deva[वृक्षकः] "small tree" (@ref[5.3.86])
13010:
When substitutes and originals are equal in number, correspondence is by order.

**Example — @ref[3.1.134]:** @deva[नन्दिग्रहिपचादिभ्यो ल्युणिन्यचः]
- @deva[ल्यु] → @deva[नन्दि]-class
- @deva[णिनि] → @deva[ग्रहि]-class
- @deva[अच्] → @deva[पच्]-class

**Example — @ref[6.1.77]:** @deva[इको यणचि]
| Original | Substitute |
|----------|------------|
| @deva[इ] | @deva[य्] |
| @deva[उ] | @deva[व्] |
| @deva[ऋ] | @deva[र्] |
| @deva[ऌ] | @deva[ल्] |

**Unequal numbers — no ordered correspondence:**
@ref[1.4.90] lists 4 meanings but only 3 words (@deva[प्रति], @deva[परि], @deva[अनु]) — each word serves all meanings.
13011:
A word with @deva[स्वरित] (circumflex) accent indicates an @deva[अधिकार] (governing rule).

Sūtras are normally unmarked. When a sūtra has svarita accent (learned from commentaries), it governs subsequent sūtras.

**Governing sūtras:**
- @deva[प्रत्ययः] (@ref[3.1.1])
- @deva[धातोः] (@ref[3.1.91])
- @deva[अङ्गस्य] (@ref[6.4.1])
- @deva[भस्य] (@ref[6.4.129])
13026:
After @deva[उप] + @deva[स्था] meaning "to attend," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

@deva[भोजनकाले उपतिष्ठते] "he attends at mealtime"
13032:
After @deva[कृ] meaning "to divulge, revile, serve, overpower, alter, recite, or act purposefully," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

| Meaning | Example |
|---------|--------|
| Divulge | @deva[आविष्कुरुते] "he reveals" |
| Revile | @deva[अपकुरुते] "he reviles" |
| Serve | @deva[पुरस्कुरुते] "he serves" |
| Overpower | @deva[अभिभवं कुरुते] "he subdues" |
| Alter | @deva[विकुरुते] "he transforms" |
| Recite | @deva[अधीते स्वाध्यायं कुरुते] "he recites" |
| Act purposefully | @deva[भोजनं कुरुते] "he prepares a meal" |
13036:
After @deva[नी] meaning "to guide worthily, lift up, make guru, determine meaning, or employ," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

| Meaning | Example |
|---------|--------|
| Guide worthily | @deva[अध्यापयमानो नयते] |
| Lift up | @deva[उन्नयते] |
| Make guru | @deva[गुरुं नयते] |
| Determine meaning | @deva[पदार्थं निर्णयते] |
| Employ | @deva[कारयमानो नयते] |
13047:
After @deva[वद्] meaning "to show proficiency, pacify, know, strive, disagree, or flatter," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

| Meaning | Example |
|---------|--------|
| Show proficiency | @deva[वेदं वदते] "he recites the Veda" |
| Pacify | @deva[शमयमानो वदते] |
| Know | @deva[जानमानो वदते] |
| Strive | @deva[प्रयतमानो वदते] |
| Disagree | @deva[विप्रवदते] |
| Flatter | @deva[प्रशंसमानो वदते] |
13048:
After @deva[वद्] meaning "speaking articulately in like manner," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

@deva[संप्रवदन्ते ब्राह्मणाः] "the Brāhmaṇas are speaking (in proper Sanskrit)"
13049:
After @deva[अनु] + @deva[वद्] used intransitively meaning "speaking in like manner," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

@deva[अनुवदते] "he repeats after"
13050:
After @deva[विप्र] + @deva[वद्] meaning "to contradict each other," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is optional.

@deva[विप्रवदन्ते] or @deva[विप्रवदन्ति वैद्याः] "the doctors disagree"
13052:
After @deva[सम्] + @deva[गॄ] meaning "to promise," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

@deva[शतं संगिरते] "he promises to pay a hundred"
13056:
After @deva[उप] + @deva[यम्] meaning "to espouse," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

@deva[भार्यामुपयच्छते] "he marries his wife"
13065:
After @deva[सम्] + @deva[क्षणु] "to sharpen," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

@deva[संक्षणुते] "he sharpens thoroughly"
13067:
After a @deva[णिच्] (causative) where the non-causal object becomes the causal agent, @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

When the object of the simple verb becomes the agent of the causative, and the fruit doesn't accrue to the causer:

**Non-causal:** @deva[देवदत्तः कटं करोति] "D. makes a mat"
**Causal:** @deva[यज्ञदत्तः कटं कारयते] "Y. has a mat made"

@deva[कट] (object) becomes understood agent of making; @deva[यज्ञदत्त] is the causer.
13070:
After causative of @deva[लि] meaning "to respect, subdue, or deceive," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

@deva[लापयते] "he causes to respect/subdue/deceive"
13071:
After causative of @deva[कृ] with @deva[मिथ्या] as upapada meaning "repeated wrong action," @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used.

@deva[मिथ्याकारयते] "he causes to do wrongly repeatedly"
13072:
After a @deva[स्वरितेत्] (svarita-marked) or @deva[ञित्] root, @deva[आत्मनेपद] is used when the fruit accrues to the agent.

The @deva[अनुवृत्ति] from @ref[1.3.12] continues.

**@deva[स्वरितेत्]:** @deva[णिच्], @deva[सन्], @deva[यङ्] are svarita-marked causative/desiderative/intensive affixes.

**@deva[ञित्]:** @deva[डुक्रीञ्] has indicatory @deva[ञ्].

**When fruit accrues — ātmanepada:**
@deva[आत्मने क्रीणीते] "he buys for himself"

**When fruit doesn't accrue — parasmaipada:**
@deva[परस्मै क्रीणाति] "he buys for another"
13082:
After @deva[परि] + @deva[मृष्], @deva[परस्मैपद] is used when fruit accrues to agent.

@deva[परिमृषति] "he endures"
14001:
From here through @ref[2.2.38], each item receives only one technical name.

When multiple names could apply, the later rule prevails (@ref[1.4.2]), and the name that would otherwise have no application takes precedence.

**Example:** A short vowel is @deva[लघु] "light" (@ref[1.4.10]) but also @deva[गुरु] "heavy" before a conjunct (@ref[1.4.11]).

| Root | Vowel status |
|------|-------------|
| @deva[भिद्] | @deva[इ] is @deva[लघु] |
| @deva[शिक्षा] | @deva[इ] is @deva[गुरु] (before @deva[क्ष]) |

The @deva[इ] in @deva[शिक्षा] has only one name: @deva[गुरु].
14002:
When rules of equal force conflict, the later rule prevails.

@deva[विप्रतिषेध] = conflict between equally strong rules. This does NOT apply when rules differ in strength:

| Stronger | Weaker |
|----------|--------|
| @deva[अपवाद] (exception) | @deva[उत्सर्ग] (general) |
| @deva[नित्य] (invariable) | @deva[अनित्य] (optional) |
| @deva[अन्तरङ्ग] (inner) | @deva[बहिरङ्ग] (outer) |

**Example of equal conflict:** @ref[7.3.102] and @ref[7.3.103]
- @ref[7.3.102]: Long vowel replaces final @deva[अ] before @deva[यञ्]-initial affixes
- @ref[7.3.103]: @deva[ए] replaces final @deva[अ] before @deva[झल्]-initial plural affixes

Before @deva[भ्यस्] (which is both @deva[यञ्] and @deva[झल्]):
@deva[वृक्ष] + @deva[भ्यस्] → @deva[वृक्षेभ्यः] (later rule @ref[7.3.103] wins)
14003:
Feminine words ending in @deva[ई] or @deva[ऊ] that denote females by their own form are called @deva[नदी].

The word must be inherently feminine — not made feminine by adding an epithet.

**Examples:** @deva[कुमारी] "maiden," @deva[यवागू] "rice gruel"

**Effect:** @deva[नदी] words take special declension. By @ref[7.3.112], @deva[आट्] augment comes before @deva[ङित्] affixes:
@deva[कुमारी] + @deva[ङे] → @deva[कुमार्यै] (dat. sg.)

**Why "ending in @deva[ई/ऊ]"?**
Feminines in other vowels decline differently:
@deva[दुहितृ] + @deva[ङे] → @deva[दुहित्रे] (not *@deva[दुहितर्यै])

**Why "denoting females"?**
Masculine @deva[ई/ऊ]-words are not @deva[नदी]:
@deva[ग्रामणी] "village head" (m.) + @deva[ङे] → @deva[ग्रामण्ये]
14004:
Feminine @deva[ई/ऊ]-words that take @deva[इयङ्/उवङ्] substitutes (@ref[6.1.77]) are not @deva[नदी] — except @deva[स्त्री].

This limits @ref[1.4.3]. Words like @deva[श्री] and @deva[भ्रू] take semivowel substitutes before vowels, so they're excluded from @deva[नदी].

**Examples:**
- @deva[श्री] "prosperity" → voc. sg. @deva[हे श्रीः] (not @deva[नदी]-type)
- @deva[भ्रू] "brow" → voc. sg. @deva[हे भ्रूः]

**Exception:** @deva[स्त्री] "woman" takes @deva[इयङ्] but remains @deva[नदी]:
@deva[स्त्री] → voc. sg. @deva[हे स्त्रि]
14005:
Before the genitive plural @deva[आम्], @deva[ई/ऊ]-words that take @deva[इयङ्/उवङ्] are optionally @deva[नदी] — but @deva[स्त्री] is always @deva[नदी].

This creates an option for the words excluded by @ref[1.4.4].

**Optional forms:**
- @deva[श्री] + @deva[आम्] → @deva[श्रीणाम्] (as @deva[नदी]) or @deva[श्रियाम्] (with @deva[इयङ्])
- @deva[भ्रू] + @deva[आम्] → @deva[भ्रूणाम्] or @deva[भ्रुवाम्]

**No option for @deva[स्त्री]:**
@deva[स्त्री] + @deva[आम्] → @deva[स्त्रीणाम्] only
14008:
@deva[पति] is @deva[घि] only in compounds.

This restricts @ref[1.4.7]. Outside compounds, @deva[पति] "lord" declines irregularly.

| Form | In compound | Standalone |
|------|-------------|------------|
| Inst. sg. | @deva[प्रजापतिना] | @deva[पत्या] |
| Dat. sg. | @deva[प्रजापतये] | @deva[पत्ये] |
| Gen. sg. | @deva[प्रजापतेः] | @deva[पत्युः] |
| Loc. sg. | @deva[प्रजापतौ] | @deva[पत्यौ] |
14011:
A short vowel followed by a conjunct consonant is @deva[गुरु] "heavy."

This overrides @ref[1.4.10]. The vowel is no longer @deva[लघु].

**Example:** @deva[शिक्षा] "learning"
- The @deva[इ] precedes @deva[क्ष] (conjunct)
- Therefore @deva[इ] is @deva[गुरु], not @deva[लघु]

**Effect on affix selection:** @ref[3.3.103] ordains @deva[अ] after roots with @deva[गुरु] penultimate:
@deva[शिक्ष्] + @deva[अ] → @deva[शिक्षा]
@deva[भिक्ष्] + @deva[अ] → @deva[भिक्षा]
14012:
A long vowel is also @deva[गुरु] "heavy."

**Summary of vowel weight:**
| Vowel type | Weight |
|------------|--------|
| Short, no following conjunct | @deva[लघु] |
| Short + conjunct | @deva[गुरु] |
| Long | @deva[गुरु] |

**Example:** @deva[ईक्ष्] + @deva[आम्] + @deva[चक्रे] → @deva[ईक्षांचक्रे] "he saw"
The @deva[ई] is @deva[गुरु], triggering @deva[आम्] augment in the perfect (@ref[3.1.36]).
14013:
Whatever stands before an affix, from the point where it begins, is called @deva[अङ्ग] "base."

An @deva[अङ्ग] is defined relative to a following affix — whether verbal or nominal.

**Examples:**
- @deva[पच्] before @deva[ति] → @deva[पच्] is @deva[अङ्ग]
- @deva[राम] before @deva[सु] → @deva[राम] is @deva[अङ्ग]
- @deva[कारक] before @deva[अण्] → @deva[कारक] is @deva[अङ्ग]

Operations described as applying to @deva[अङ्ग] (@ref[6.4.1] onward) affect the base before its affix.
14014:
A word ending in @deva[सुप्] (case-affix) or @deva[तिङ्] (verb-ending) is called @deva[पद] "inflected word."

**Nominal @deva[पद]:** @deva[ब्राह्मण] + @deva[जस्] → @deva[ब्राह्मणाः]
**Verbal @deva[पद]:** @deva[पच्] + @deva[अन्ति] → @deva[पचन्ति]

**Effect:** Word-final rules (@ref[8.1.16] onward) apply to @deva[पद]-final letters:
- @deva[स्] → @deva[विसर्ग]
- Voice assimilation
- Final consonant simplification
14016:
Before an affix with indicatory @deva[स्] (@deva[सित्]), the preceding word is @deva[पद].

This excepts @ref[1.4.18] (which would make it @deva[भ]).

**Example:** @deva[भवत्] + @deva[छस्] (@ref[4.2.115]) → @deva[भवदीयः] "belonging to you"

The @deva[स्] in @deva[छस्] is indicatory, so @deva[भवत्] is treated as @deva[पद], and @ref[7.1.2] applies.
14018:
Before @deva[य्]-initial or vowel-initial affixes (within @deva[सु] to @deva[कप्], excluding @deva[सर्वनामस्थान]), the preceding word is @deva[भ].

This overrides @deva[पद] status from @ref[1.4.17].

**@deva[य्]-initial:**
@deva[गर्ग] + @deva[यञ्] → @deva[गार्ग्यः] "descendant of Garga"
As @deva[भ], final @deva[अ] is elided by @ref[6.4.148].

**Vowel-initial:**
@deva[दक्ष] + @deva[इञ्] → @deva[दाक्षिः]
14023:
The term @deva[कारक] governs the following sūtras.

A @deva[कारक] is anything that contributes to accomplishing an action.

**Example:** "Rāma cooks food in a vessel, by fire from the furnace, for his master."

| Kāraka | Role | Example |
|--------|------|--------|
| @deva[कर्तृ] | Agent | Rāma |
| @deva[कर्मन्] | Object | food |
| @deva[अधिकरण] | Locus | vessel |
| @deva[करण] | Instrument | fire |
| @deva[अपादान] | Source | furnace |
| @deva[सम्प्रदान] | Recipient | master |
14051:
That @deva[कारक] which is not covered by any special relation (ablation, etc.) is also called @deva[कर्म].

Some verbs take an "unmentioned" (@deva[अकथित]) object in addition to their direct object.

**Examples:**
- @deva[गां दोग्धि पयः] "milks the cow for milk" — @deva[गाम्] is the direct object; @deva[पयः] is akathita
- @deva[माणवकं पन्थानं याचते] "asks the boy for the way" — @deva[माणवकम्] is direct; @deva[पन्थानम्] is akathita

**The five special relations:** @deva[अपादान], @deva[सम्प्रदान], @deva[करण], @deva[अधिकरण], @deva[कर्तृ]
14052:
For verbs meaning motion, knowledge, eating, having a literary work as object, or intransitive verbs — when @deva[णिच्] (causative) is added, the original agent becomes the @deva[कर्म].

**Examples:**
| Primitive | Causative | Analysis |
|-----------|-----------|----------|
| @deva[देवदत्तो ग्रामं गच्छति] | @deva[देवदत्तं ग्रामं गमयति] | Devadatta (agent) → object |
| @deva[देवदत्तो मन्त्रमधीते] | @deva[देवदत्तं मन्त्रमध्यापयति] | "causes D. to study the mantra" |
| @deva[देवदत्तो भुङ्क्ते] | @deva[देवदत्तं भोजयति] | "causes D. to eat" |

**Note:** The original @deva[कर्तृ] takes @deva[द्वितीया] in the causative.
14053:
For @deva[हृ] "to take/lose" and @deva[कृ] "to make" — the primitive agent optionally becomes @deva[कर्म] in the causative.

**Examples:**
| Option 1 (agent as कर्म) | Option 2 (agent as कर्तृ) |
|-------------------------|-------------------------|
| @deva[माणवकं भारं हारयति] | @deva[माणवकेन भारं हारयति] |
| @deva[माणवकं कटं कारयति] | @deva[माणवकेन कटं कारयति] |

In Option 1, the boy (@deva[माणवक]) takes accusative. In Option 2, instrumental.
14054:
That which the speaker conceives as the independent source of action is called @deva[कर्तृ] (agent).

The agent is "self-dependent" (@deva[स्वतन्त्र]) — not subordinate to another in performing the action.

**Examples:**
- @deva[देवदत्तः पचति] "Devadatta cooks" — Devadatta is @deva[कर्तृ]
- @deva[स्थाली पचति] "The pot cooks" — even the pot can be @deva[कर्तृ] if conceived as independent

**Key point:** @deva[कर्तृ] is determined by the speaker's conception, not objective reality.
14055:
That which impels the independent agent is called @deva[हेतु] (cause) — and it too is called @deva[कर्तृ].

In causative constructions, the causer (@deva[प्रयोजक]) becomes the @deva[कर्तृ].

**Example:**
- @deva[देवदत्तः याज्ञदत्तेन कटं कारयति] "Devadatta causes Yājñadatta to make a mat"
  - @deva[देवदत्त] = @deva[हेतु] (causer) = @deva[कर्तृ]
  - @deva[याज्ञदत्त] = @deva[कर्म] (by @ref[1.4.52])

**Verb form:** @deva[णिच्] (causative) is used when @deva[हेतु] is the agent — @ref[3.1.26]
14056:
From here up to @ref[1.4.97] (@deva[अधिरीश्वरे]), all terms taught are called @deva[निपात] (particles).

This is an @deva[अधिकार] (governing rule) that extends over the following sūtras.

**Scope:** Sūtras @ref[1.4.56] through @ref[1.4.97] define various types of @deva[निपात].
14057:
The words @deva[च] "and" etc. are called @deva[निपात] when they do not denote substances.

**Common निपातs:**
| Word | Meaning |
|------|---------|
| @deva[च] | and |
| @deva[वा] | or |
| @deva[एव] | only, exactly |
| @deva[एवम्] | thus, so |
| @deva[नूनम्] | certainly |
| @deva[खलु] | indeed |
| @deva[हि] | for, because |
| @deva[मा] | don't (prohibition) |

**Key condition:** @deva[असत्त्वे] — when NOT denoting a substance.
14058:
The words @deva[प्र] etc. are called @deva[निपात] when not denoting substances.

**The 22 प्रादयः (prepositions):**
@deva[प्र], @deva[परा], @deva[अप], @deva[सम्], @deva[अनु], @deva[अव], @deva[निस्], @deva[निर्], @deva[दुस्], @deva[दुर्], @deva[वि], @deva[आङ्], @deva[नि], @deva[अधि], @deva[अपि], @deva[अति], @deva[सु], @deva[उद्], @deva[अभि], @deva[प्रति], @deva[परि], @deva[उप]

These have grammatical functions when joined to verbs (see @ref[1.4.59]).
14059:
The words @deva[प्र] etc. are called @deva[उपसर्ग] when joined with a verb (@deva[क्रियायोगे]).

**Effect:** When @deva[प्रादयः] become @deva[उपसर्ग], they trigger phonological rules.

**Example:**
- @deva[प्र] + @deva[नयति] → @deva[प्रणयति] (न → ण by @ref[8.4.1])

The designation @deva[उपसर्ग] is needed for rules like @ref[8.4.1] (@deva[रषाभ्यां नो णः समानपदे]).
14060:
The words @deva[प्र] etc. are also called @deva[गति] when joined with a verb.

**Effect:** The @deva[गति] designation triggers @ref[2.2.18], which causes @deva[त्वा] → @deva[ल्यप्] (य) in absolutives.

**Example:**
- @deva[कृ] → @deva[कृत्वा] (simple absolutive)
- @deva[प्र] + @deva[कृ] → @deva[प्रकृत्य] (NOT *प्रकृत्वा)

**Note:** @deva[गति] and @deva[उपसर्ग] are both names for the same words in verbal composition.
14061:
The words @deva[उरी] etc., words ending in @deva[च्वि] @ref[5.4.50], and words ending in @deva[डाच्] @ref[5.4.57] are called @deva[गति] when compounded with @deva[भू], @deva[कृ], or @deva[अस्].

**Examples:**
- @deva[उरीकृत्य] "having accepted"
- @deva[शुक्लीकृत्य] "having made white" (@deva[च्वि] derivative)
- @deva[ऊर्ध्वीकृत्य] "having raised" (@deva[डाच्] derivative)

**The उर्यादि list:** @deva[उरी], @deva[अन्तरा], @deva[प्रादुस्], @deva[अस्तम्], @deva[आविस्], @deva[तिरस्]
14062:
An onomatopoeic word (@deva[अनुकरण]) is called @deva[गति] when NOT followed by @deva[इति].

**Examples:**
- @deva[खाट्कृत्य] "having made the sound 'khāṭ'" — @deva[गति] applies
- @deva[खाट् इति कृत्वा] "having made 'khāṭ'" — @deva[गति] does NOT apply (इति present)

**Effect:** When @deva[गति] applies, @deva[त्वा] → @deva[ल्यप्] by @ref[2.2.18].
14063:
The words @deva[सत्] and @deva[असत्] are called @deva[गति] when meaning "respect" and "disrespect" respectively.

**Examples:**
- @deva[सत्कृत्य] "having honored" (सत् = respect)
- @deva[असत्कृत्य] "having dishonored" (असत् = disrespect)

**Not गति when:** @deva[सत्] means "existing" or @deva[असत्] means "non-existing."
14064:
The word @deva[अलम्] is called @deva[गति] when meaning "ornament."

**Four meanings of अलम्:**
1. Prohibition — @deva[अलं गमनेन] "don't go"
2. Competence — @deva[अलं कार्याय] "capable for the task"
3. Enough — @deva[अलं भक्तेन] "enough food"
4. **Ornament** — @deva[अलंकृत्य] "having adorned" (गति applies here)
14065:
The word @deva[अन्तर्] is called @deva[गति] when meaning "non-acceptance/rejection."

**Example:**
- @deva[अन्तर्कृत्य] "having rejected/set aside"

**Not गति when:** @deva[अन्तर्] means "inside" — @deva[अन्तः कृत्वा] "having placed inside."
14066:
The words @deva[कणे] and @deva[मनस्] are called @deva[गति] when meaning "satisfaction of desire."

**Examples:**
- @deva[कणेहत्य पयः पिबति] "drinks milk to satisfaction"
- @deva[मनोहत्य भुङ्क्ते] "eats to heart's content"

**Note:** @deva[श्रद्धाप्रतीघात] = satisfaction, the quelling of desire.
14067:
The indeclinable @deva[पुरः] "in front" is called @deva[गति] when compounded with a verb.

**Examples:**
- @deva[पुरस्कृत्य] "having placed in front, having honored"
- @deva[पुरोधाय] "having placed before"

**Formation:** @deva[पूर्व] + @deva[असि] @ref[5.3.39] → @deva[पुरस्] (indeclinable by @ref[1.1.38])
14068:
The indeclinable @deva[अस्तम्] "setting, disappearance" is called @deva[गति].

**Example:**
- @deva[अस्तंगत्य सविता पुनरुदेति] "the sun, having set, rises again"

**Meaning:** @deva[अस्तम्] = "not visible, gone down" (of celestial bodies).
14069:
The indeclinable @deva[अच्छ] "towards, before" is called @deva[गति] with verbs of motion or with @deva[वद्] "to speak."

**Examples:**
- @deva[अच्छगत्य] "having gone towards"
- @deva[अच्छवाद्य] "having spoken to"

**Not गति with other verbs:** @deva[अच्छ कृत्वा] (not *अच्छकृत्य).
14070:
The pronoun @deva[अदस्] "that" is called @deva[गति] when NOT addressing another.

**Example:**
- @deva[अदःकृत्य] "having made that" (internal thought/action)

**Not गति:** When giving direction to another — @deva[अदः कृत्वा] "having made that" (addressing someone).
14071:
The word @deva[तिरस्] is called @deva[गति] when meaning "disappearance."

**Examples:**
- @deva[तिरोभूय] "having disappeared"
- @deva[तिरोभूतम्] "disappeared"

**Not गति:** When @deva[तिरस्] means "across/beyond" — @deva[तिरो वनं गच्छति] "goes across the forest."
14072:
The word @deva[तिरस्] is OPTIONALLY called @deva[गति] when followed by @deva[कृ].

**Both forms valid:**
- @deva[तिरस्कृत्य] (गति applies, त्वा → य)
- @deva[तिरः कृत्वा] (गति doesn't apply)

**Note:** This is @deva[प्राप्तविभाषा] — optional application of an otherwise obligatory rule.
14073:
The words @deva[उपाजे] and @deva[अन्वाजे] "supporting the weak" are optionally @deva[गति] with @deva[कृ].

**Both valid:**
- @deva[उपाजेकृत्य] or @deva[उपाजे कृत्वा] "having given support"
- @deva[अन्वाजेकृत्य] or @deva[अन्वाजे कृत्वा] "having assisted"
14074:
The words @deva[साक्षात्] "in presence of" etc. are optionally @deva[गति] with @deva[कृ].

**Examples:**
- @deva[साक्षात्कृत्य] or @deva[साक्षात् कृत्वा] "having witnessed directly"

**The साक्षात्प्रभृति list includes:** @deva[साक्षात्], @deva[अन्तः], etc.

**Implied sense:** The @deva[च्वि] force is understood — making something what it was not before.
14075:
The words @deva[उरसि] "in the breast" and @deva[मनसि] "in the mind" are optionally @deva[गति] with @deva[कृ], provided the sense is NOT "placing."

**गति applies (not placing):**
- @deva[उरसिकृत्य] "having embraced" (held to chest)
- @deva[मनसिकृत्य] "having kept in mind"

**गति doesn't apply (placing):**
- @deva[उरसि कृत्वा] "having placed on the chest"
14076:
The words @deva[मध्ये] "in the middle," @deva[पदे] "in the foot," and @deva[निवचने] "speechless" are optionally @deva[गति] with @deva[कृ], when NOT meaning "placing."

**Examples:**
- @deva[मध्येकृत्य] or @deva[मध्ये कृत्वा] "having interrupted"
- @deva[पदेकृत्य] "having trod upon"
- @deva[निवचनेकृत्य] "having silenced"
14077:
The words @deva[हस्ते] and @deva[पाणौ] "in the hand" are ALWAYS @deva[गति] with @deva[कृ] when meaning "marriage."

**Examples:**
- @deva[पाणौकृत्य] "having married" (taking the hand)
- @deva[हस्तेकृत्य] "having married"

**Not गति:** When literally placing in hand — @deva[हस्ते कृत्वा] "having placed in hand."

**Note:** @deva[नित्यम्] = always, obligatorily (not optional here).
14078:
The indeclinable @deva[प्राध्वम्] is always @deva[गति] with @deva[कृ] when meaning "binding."

**Example:**
- @deva[प्राध्वंकृत्य] "having bound/tied"

**Meaning:** @deva[प्राध्वम्] = "favorably, suitably" but here specifically "binding."
14079:
The words @deva[जीविका] and @deva[उपनिषद्] are @deva[गति] with @deva[कृ] when meaning "likeness/resemblance."

**Examples:**
- @deva[जीविकाकृत्य] "having made it like a livelihood"
- @deva[उपनिषत्कृत्य] "having made it like a secret doctrine"

**Sense:** Treating something AS IF it were that thing.
14080:
The @deva[गति] and @deva[उपसर्ग] words are placed BEFORE the verbal root (@deva[प्राग्धातोः]).

**Principle:** These are prefixes, not suffixes.

**Examples:**
- @deva[प्र] + @deva[कृ] → @deva[प्रकृत्य] (prefix position)
- @deva[अस्तम्] + @deva[गम्] → @deva[अस्तंगत्य] (prefix position)

**Note:** @deva[ते] in the sūtra refers back to both @deva[गति] and @deva[उपसर्ग].
14081:
In Vedic literature (@deva[छन्दस्]), @deva[गति] and @deva[उपसर्ग] may also be placed AFTER the verb.

**Classical Sanskrit:** Prefix position only — @deva[प्रकृत्य]
**Vedic Sanskrit:** Either position — @deva[आ यातम् उप निष्कृतम्] "come here, having prepared"

**Note:** This flexibility is a Vedic license not available in classical Sanskrit.
14082:
In Vedic literature, @deva[गति] and @deva[उपसर्ग] may be separated from the verb by intervening words.

**Example:** @deva[इन्द्र वायू इमे सुता उप प्रयोभिरागतम्]
"O Indra and Vāyu, these (soma juices) are pressed — come with your teams"

Here @deva[उप] and @deva[आगतम्] are separated by other words.

**Classical Sanskrit:** No such separation allowed — prefix must be adjacent to verb.
14083:
From here to @ref[1.4.97], the terms taught are called @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय].

@deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] = particles that govern a noun (in accusative) and qualify a verb.

**Difference from उपसर्ग:**
- @deva[उपसर्ग] — directly prefixed to verb, modifies its meaning
- @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] — governs a separate noun, relates it to the verb

**Example:** @deva[वृक्षं प्रति विद्योतते विद्युत्] "Lightning flashes towards the tree"
14084:
The word @deva[अनु] is @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] when denoting a "sign" or indicator.

**Example:** @deva[धूममनु अग्निः] "Fire (is inferred) from smoke"
— Smoke is the @deva[लक्षण] (sign) that indicates fire.

**Sense:** "by means of," "indicated by"
14085:
The word @deva[अनु] is @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] when having the sense of the instrumental case (@deva[तृतीया]).

**Example:** @deva[नदीमनु अवसिता सेना] "The army is encamped along the river"

**Sense:** "along with," "following"
14086:
The word @deva[अनु] is @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] when meaning "inferior/subordinate to."

**Example:** @deva[यूपमनु आदित्यः] "The sun (appears) after/below the sacrificial post"

**Sense:** Comparison, with the governed noun as the standard.
14087:
The word @deva[उप] is @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] when meaning "superior to" or "inferior to."

**Examples:**
- @deva[उपखार्यां द्रोणः] "A droṇa is close to (just under) a khārī" (inferior)
- @deva[उप द्रोणं खारी] "A khārī is close to (just over) a droṇa" (superior)

**Sense:** Proximity in comparison, either above or below.
14088:
The words @deva[अप] and @deva[परि] are @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] when meaning "exclusion."

**Examples:**
- @deva[अपत्रिगर्त्तेभ्यो वृष्टो देवः] "It rained except on the Trigarttas"
- @deva[परित्रिगर्त्तेभ्यो वृष्टो देवः] (same meaning)

**Sense:** "with the exception of," "excluding"
14089:
The word @deva[आङ्] is @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] when expressing a limit (@deva[मर्यादा]).

**Examples:**
- @deva[आ मुक्तेः संसारः] "Saṃsāra extends up to liberation" (exclusive)
- @deva[आ कुमारं यशः पाणिनेः] "Pāṇini's fame extends to (includes) children" (inclusive)

**Two senses:** Inclusive limit or exclusive limit — both expressed by @deva[वचन] in the sūtra.
14090:
The words @deva[प्रति], @deva[परि], and @deva[अनु] are @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] in five senses:

| Sense | Term | Example |
|-------|------|---------|
| Direction/sign | @deva[लक्षण] | @deva[वृक्षं प्रति विद्योतते] "flashes toward the tree" |
| Circumstance | @deva[इत्थंभूताख्यान] | @deva[मां प्रति वर्तते] "behaves regarding me" |
| Division | @deva[भाग] | @deva[यथा प्रति पुरुषं दीयताम्] "give per person" |
| Distribution | @deva[वीप्सा] | @deva[वृक्षं वृक्षं प्रति] "tree by tree" |
14091:
The word @deva[अभि] is @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] in the senses of direction, circumstance, and distribution — but NOT division/share.

**Examples:**
- @deva[वृक्षमभि विद्योतते] "flashes toward the tree" (direction)
- @deva[मामभि वर्तते] "behaves regarding me" (circumstance)

**Not कर्मप्रवचनीय:** @deva[अभि] doesn't express "share/portion" like @deva[प्रति] does.
14092:
The word @deva[प्रति] is @deva[कर्मप्रवचनीय] in two special senses:
